revision.text:
{{ref improve|date=July 2017}} {{Centurybox|26}} The '''26th century''' of the [[anno Domini]] ([[common era|common]]) era will span from January 1, 2501, to December 31, 2600, of the [[Gregorian calendar]]. ==Astronomical events== ===List of the long total solar eclipses=== * June 14, 2504: [[Solar eclipse]],[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2504-06-14.gif Solar eclipse of June 14, 2504] (7 min 10 s), of [[saros (astronomy)|saros]] 145. * June 25, 2522: at 9:04 [[Dynamic time|TD]], total solar eclipse{{Cite web |url=http://sunearth.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2522-06-25.gif |title=Solar eclipse of June 25, 2522 |access-date=2007-03-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615182835/http://sunearth.gsfc.nasa.gov/eclipse/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2522-06-25.gif |archive-date=2007-06-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} of 7min 12s, "crowning" at the top the series of [http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsaros/SEsaros145.html saros 145].The serie from the last total eclipse of the last millennium taken on [[Solar eclipse of August 11, 1999|August 11, 1999]]. * July 5, 2540: Solar eclipse,[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2540-07-05.gif Solar eclipse of July 5, 2540] (7 min 04 s), of saros 145. * July 17, 2558: Solar eclipse,[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2558-07-17.gif Éclipse solaire du July 17, 2558] (6 min 43 s), of saros 145. * August 6, 2567: Solar eclipse,[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2567-08-06.gif Solar eclipse of August 6, 2567] (6 min 26 s), of saros 164. * August 16, 2585: Solar eclipse,[http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/5MCSEmap/2501-2600/2585-08-16.gif Solar eclipse of August 16, 2585] (6 min 16 s), of [http://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsaros/SEsaros164.html saros 164]. ====Particular eclipse prediction==== * May 5, 2600: First total solar eclipse[https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsearch/SEsearchmap.php?Ecl=26000505 Solar eclipse of May 5, 2600] visible from [[London]] since 2151.[https://eclipse.gsfc.nasa.gov/SEsearch/SEsearchmap.php?Ecl=21510614 Solar eclipse of June 14, 2151]
The width of its path is predicted to be exceptionally wide at its maximum point. ===Other phenomena=== * April 7, 2515: At 10:37 [[Universal Time|UTC]], [[Mars]] will [[occultation|occult]] [[Neptune]].[http://transit.savage-garden.org/mutual.html Mutual Planetary Transits; Fifteen millennium catalog; Period 2 001 AD – 3 000 AD] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105163356/http://transit.savage-garden.org/mutual.html |date=January 5, 2016 }} * January 25, 2518: At 22:41 UTC, [[Venus]] will occult [[Saturn]]. * 2562: The [[dwarf planet]] [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]] will have completed one orbit of the Sun since its discovery in 2005. * 2599: [[Triple conjunction]] Mars–[[Jupiter]]. ==Science fiction set in the 26th century== ===Literature=== * [[Aldous Huxley]]'s [[dystopia]]n novel ''[[Brave New World]]'' is set in 2540. * The "Fiat Homo" section of ''[[A Canticle for Leibowitz]]'' by [[Walter M. Miller, Jr.|Walter Miller]] takes place in the 26th century. * Anthony Meredith writes the foreword to the Everhard Manuscript in Jack London's ''[[The Iron Heel]]'' around this time. * In the early 26th century, humans make [[First contact (science fiction)|first contact]] with [[Pierson's Puppeteers]] in [[Larry Niven]]'s ''[[Known Space]]'' universe. * In the novel ''[[More than Weird]]'' by [[English-Canadian]] author [[Martyn Godfrey]], a [[Gynoid]] named Susie travels from 2537 to 1987 to [[Dawson Creek]] to find a human teenager to take to the future to put him in a human zoo. * Most of the events of the novel ''[[Revelation Space]]'' take place in 2566 with flashbacks to 2524 and earlier centuries. * [[Bernice Summerfield]], a character created in ''[[Doctor Who]]'' novels and later [[Doctor Who spin-offs|spun off]] into her own range of novels and [[radio drama|audio dramas]], was born in 2540, and published an archaeological book, ''Down Among the Dead Men'', in 2566. * Nevil Kingston-Brown, an [[Australia]]n physicist in [[H. P. Lovecraft]]'s "[[The Shadow Out of Time]]", will die in 2518. ===Film=== * In the film ''[[Aditya 369]]'', the protagonists reach a post-apocalyptic world on 5 April 2504. It is revealed that most of the world was destroyed in [[World War III]] and the surface of the Earth is not suitable for humans. * The third and final portion of [[Darren Aronofsky]]'s film ''[[The Fountain (film)|The Fountain]]'' takes place in the 26th century with future astronaut Tom Verde, played by [[Hugh Jackman]]. * The film ''[[Idiocracy]]'', in which an average man (played by [[Luke Wilson]]) from 2005 is suspended in hibernation and wakes up 500 years later, is set in 2505. * The film ''[[Pitch Black (film)|Pitch Black]]'' takes place in 2578, and its [[sequel]] ''[[The Chronicles of Riddick]]'' takes place in 2583.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} * The film ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]'' is set in 2517, and follow Space Captain and Unification War veteran, [[Malcolm Reynolds]], and his crew, across various [[planet]]s. ===Television=== * The [[television program|TV show]] ''[[Cleopatra 2525]]'' is set in 2525. (The theme song for the show is a parody of the song "[[In the Year 2525]]", mingled with the sound effects of futuristic weaponry.) * The [[television program|TV show]] ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]'' is set in 2517, and follow Space Captain and Unification War veteran, [[Malcolm Reynolds]], and his crew, across various [[planet]]s. * The eighth season of ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'' is set in 2525. According to the show, 2525 is the year in which [[End time|Earth is destroyed]]. * The ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serial ''[[Earthshock]]'', featuring the hijacking of a space freighter by [[Cyberman|Cybermen]], is set largely in the year 2526. * The ''[[Doctor Who]]'' serials ''[[Frontier in Space]]'' and ''[[Planet of the Daleks]]'' take place in 2540. * In the ''[[South Park]]'' episodes "[[Go God Go]]" and "[[Go God Go XII]]", [[Eric Cartman]] freezes himself in 2006 because he is too impatient to wait three weeks for the release of the [[Wii]] video game console. He is accidentally left frozen until 2546. * In the ''[[Star Trek: Enterprise]]'' episode "Azati Prime", Captain [[Jonathan Archer]] is briefly transported to a possible future 26th century (in the ''Star Trek'' universe) in which [[Klingon]] and [[Xindi (Star Trek)|Xindi]] crewmen serve the [[United Federation of Planets]]. Archer visits a possible version of USS ''Enterprise'' (NCC-1701-J). * The ''[[Planet of the Apes (TV series)|Planet of the Apes]]'' episode "Escape from Tomorrow" features a history book with a photograph of [[New York City]] in 2503. * The ''[[Medabots]]'' series are set in the 26th century. * ''[[Miles from Tomorrowland]]'' is set in 2551. * The ''[[Tom and Jerry]]'' episode "[[Guided Mouse-ille]]" takes place in 2565. ===Video games=== *The ''[[Halo (series)|Halo]]'' series is set in the 26th century. ''[[Halo: Combat Evolved]]'', ''[[Halo 2]]'', ''[[Halo 3]]'', ''[[Halo 3: ODST]]'' & ''[[Halo: Reach]]'' take place between 2552 and 2553; the prequel [[Halo Wars]] takes place in 2531. ''[[Halo 4]]'' takes place in 2557. ''[[Halo 5: Guardians]]'' takes place in 2558. ''[[Halo Wars 2]]'' takes place in 2559. * In ''[[R-Type Final]]'' the bonus ending where player sent from 2164 to 2501, they have only a chance to finish their journey home. * The video game ''[[Bulletstorm]]'' is set in this century. * The ''[[Dead Space (series)|Dead Space]]'' game series takes place in the early 26th century, with "[[Dead Space (video game)|Dead Space]]" taking place in 2508, "[[Dead Space 2]]" in 2511 and "[[Dead Space 3]]" in 2514. * The [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] video game ''[[Dino Crisis 3]]'' is set in a spaceship in 2548. * The [[Nintendo 64]] game ''[[F-Zero X]]'' and the [[Nintendo GameCube]] game ''[[F-Zero GX]]'' take place in an unspecified year in the 26th century. However, in the [[Game Boy Advance]] game ''[[F-Zero: GP Legend (video game)|F-Zero GP Legend]]'', it is stated that the game takes place in the 23rd century in 2201. * The ''[[StarCraft (series)|StarCraft]]'' series is set within the early 26th century. * The [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]] game ''[[Super Spy Hunter]]'' takes place in 2525. * The computer game ''[[Tachyon: The Fringe]]'' takes place in the 26th century, as stated by Commander Alberion Obulo in the intro. * In the ''[[Xenosaga]]'' universe, 2510 is the year that the worldwide organization in charge of the space emigration plan changes the dating system from "[[Anno Domini|A.D.]]" to "[[Xenosaga (other)#T.C.|T.C.]]" * The top-down 2D [[Role-playing video game]] [[Space Station 13]] takes place in 2560. This year, however, changes with the current year in real life. ===Comics=== * [[Battle Angel Alita]] ([[Gunm]]) is set during this century. === Music === * "[[In the Year 2525]]", a 1969 song by [[Zager and Evans]], describes what life is like in 2525 (and later 3535, 4545 and many others). Disturbing predictions are given for each selected year. * "Pretty Good Looking", a song by [[the White Stripes]] on their album "[[De Stijl (album)|De Stijl]]", references the Zager and Evans song with the line "This feeling's still gonna linger on/until the year 2525 now." ===Other=== * One possible alternative future for the [[tabletop role-playing game]] ''[[Mutants & Masterminds]]'' is set in [[Freedom City]] in 2525. ==Population of Earth== Physicist [[Stephen Hawking]], at a [[White House]] lecture in 1999, remarked that if there is no [[space colonization]], population expansion continued unabated and the people of the Earth continued to use power at the rate they did then, then by the year 2600, people would be standing shoulder to shoulder and the Earth would glow red hot.http://clinton4.nara.gov/Initiatives/Millennium/shawking.html ==Notes and references==
==Centuries and millennia== {{Centuries}} {{DEFAULTSORT:26th Century}} [[Category:26th century| ]] [[Category:Centuries]] [[Category:Centuries in the future]] [[Category:3rd millennium]] [[Category:Future timelines|2600]]

[[Image:Assem akram.jpg|right|thumb|Assem Akram]]'''Assem Akram''' (born 1965) is an Afghan historian, and author from [[Kabul]], [[Afghanistan]].
Akram holds a [[PhD]] in history from the [[University of Paris]].
==Works==
* The '''1492' Conspiracy, A Machiavellian Plot to Seize the Holy Land and Keep the White House''', Three-Horned Lion, June 2006, USA, 304 pages, English. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060909163204/http://www.threehornedlion.com/] * '''A Study On Mohammad Daoud Khan (Negahe ba Shakhsiat, Nazariat wa Siassat ha-ye Sardar Mohammad Daoud)''', Mizan Publishing, August 2001, Alexandria-VA, 440 pages in [[Persian language|Persian]]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040720100757/http://www.sardardaoud.com/] * '''History of the War of Afghanistan (Histoire de la guerre d’Afghanistan)''', Balland Publishing House, December 1996, Paris, 641 pages, in French. Re-printed in June 1998 & in December 2001 with updates. * '''Fatal Ochre (Ocre fatale)''', Balland Publishing House, February 2001, Paris; fiction, 230 pages, in French.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Assem, Akram}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Historians of Asia]] [[Category:Afghan writers]] [[Category:Afghan historians]]
{{afghanistan-historian-stub}}

'''''Anonym[o]us Valesianus''''' (Excerptum Valesianum [I and II]) is the conventional title of a compilation of two fragmentary [[vulgar Latin]] [[chronicle]]s, named for its 17th-century editor, [[Henri Valois|Henri Valois, or Henricus Valesius]] (1603–76), who published the text for the first time in 1636, together with his first printed edition of the [[Ammianus Marcellinus|''Res Gestae'' of Ammianus Marcellinus]]. It took almost another fifty years when his brother Hadrian re-edited the work of Anonymus in the edition of Ammianus Marcellinus in 1681. It was the first time when Excerpta Valesiana, that is the edition of the Pars Posterior was clearly separated from other fragments.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Kovács|first=Tamás|year=2017|title=Some remarks on Anonymus Valesianus Pars Posterior|url=http://publicatio.bibl.u-szeged.hu/12031/1/KOVACS_Some_remarks_on_Anonymus_Valesianus_Pars_Posterior.pdf|journal=Chronica: Annual of the Institute of History|volume=13|pages=5–16|via=SZTE Publicatio}}</ref>
The texts exist only in a single ninth-century manuscript in Berlin.<ref>Codex Berolinensis 1885.</ref> The collection later turned up in the Jesuit ''Collège de Clermont'' in Paris. The parchment bundle, originally consisted of 34 flimsy layers – a manuscript prepared by nine different hands – was later ordered and attached together according to the hands. The collection appeared in the catalogue of the Jesuit college at the occasion of the sale of the library by auction in 1764. The collection was sold and transferred to a certain Johannes Meermann (''Codex Meermannus'' 794) in the Hague. Following the death of Meermann, the collection was possessed by an English collector Sir Thomas Phillipps (''Codex Phillippsianus 1885''). Later, through the heirs, it was taken by the German State Library in Berlin in 1887 where it is accessible today under the shelf-mark: ‘''Ms. Phill. 1885’''.<ref name=":0" /> They are sometimes referred to as the '''''Excerpta Valesiani'''''.
The work of the Anonymus Valesianus is a debated issue of historiography for more than one hundred years, all the more so as both the identity of the author and the circumstances of the compilation of the work are obscure.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Greek and Roman Historiography in the Late Antiquity Fourth to Sixth Century A.D.|last=Winkelmann|first=Friedhelm|last3=|publisher=Brill|year=2003|isbn=90 04 11275 8|location=Leiden - Boston|pages=3–43|chapter=Historiography int the Age of Constantine|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
== Anonymus Valesianus I == ''Anonymus Valesianus'' I, sometimes given the separate conventional title '''''Origo Constantini Imperatoris''''' ("The Lineage of the Emperor Constantine") possibly dates from around 390, and is generally regarded as providing a reliable source. The beginning of Origo already looks like the final sentence of an account on the rule of [[Diocletian]] and [[Maximian]].<ref name=":1" /> In 1963 Arnaldo Momigliano summarized the results of scholarship on Origo Constantini in the words that ''“All is in doubt about the first part of the Anonymus Valesianus”.'' There are questions left, with regard to the date of Origo’s editions, sources, and revisions, which have not yet found convincing answers.<ref name=":1" />
== Anonymus Valesianus II == ''Anonymus Valesianus'' II, sometimes referred to as the '''''Pars Posterior''''', written after 526 and probably between 540 and 550.<ref>"The Anonymous Valesianus covered the period 474-526 essentially from a Catholic-exarchate point of view and was probably written near Ravenna ca. 540-550" (Thomas S. Burns, ''The Ostrogoths: kingship and society'', 1980:66).</ref> The text, which mostly deals with the reign of the [[Goth]]ic king in Italy, [[Theodoric the Great]]. The identity of the author and the circumstances of the compilation of the Pars Posterior is obscure, however a few scholars think it "based on a no longer extant chronicle by the [[bishop of Ravenna]], [[Maximianus of Ravenna|Maximianus]]".<ref>Geoffrey Nathan, "The fate of [[Romulus Augustulus]]", ''[[Classica et Mediaevalia|Classica et Mediaevalia: Revue Danoise de Philologie et d'Histoire]]'' 1993:268 note 23; the connection to Maximianus was made by Thomas Hodgkin, ''Italy and Her Invaders: The Ostrogothic invasion, 476-535''. 1896:261.</ref>
The Pars Posterior consists of 60 chapters and it presents the chain of events as a chronicle from Chapter 36 to 59: from the rule of [[Zeno (emperor)|Emperor Zeno]], through the decline of the power of [[Odoacer]], up to the succession of [[Theoderic the Great|Theodoric the Great]] in 493. In the next section, from Chapter 60 to 79, the description of the rule of [[Theodoric the Great]] – the Italian ruler of Germanic origin – can be found. Besides the description of political events the author dwells on portraying the major virtues of the ruler through different narratives. In the closing section (Chapter 80 to 96) the author describes the tragic years of [[Theoderic the Great|Theodoric's]] rule.<ref name=":0" />
The work was used by [[Edward Gibbon]] as a major source for the Roman perspective on the [[Ostrogothic Kingdom|Ostrogothic]] period in his ''[[The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire|History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire]]''.<ref>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=awMQRkgTaKwC&pg=PA143 |title=Edward Gibbon and Empire |author=T.S.Brown |chapter=Gibbon, Hodgkin and the invaders of Italy|isbn=9780521525053 |date=1991-08-30 }}</ref>
==Further reading== * James Noel Adams, ''The Text and Language of a Vulgar Latin Chronicle (Anonymus Valesianus II)'' (University of London), 1976; * S.J.B. Barnish, "The Anonymus Valesianus II as a source for the last years of Theoderic", ''Latomus'', '''42''' (1983:572-596). * Brian Croke, „Latin Historiography and the Barbarian Kingdoms.” in G. Marasco, ''Greek & Roman Historiography in Late Antiquity Fourth to Sixth Century A.D.'', Ledien-Boston 2003 * Tamás Kovács, "Some remarks on Anonymus Valesianus' Pars Posterior", ''Chronica: Annual of the Institute of History'', '''13''' (2017, 5-16). * Ingemar König (ed.), ''Anonymus Valesianus, Origo Constantini''. Part I : Text und Kommentar'', (Trierer Historische Förschungen) Trier 1987.'' * Ingemar König, ''Aus der Zeit Theodorichs des Großen: Einleitung, Text, Übersetzung, Kommentar einer anonymen Quelle'', Darmstadt 1997. * Isabel Lasala Navarro, Pilar López Hernando, "Chronica Theodericiana, comentario, notas y traduccion", ''Habis'', ''40''' (2009:251-275)
==External links== * [http://genianet.com/content/origo/origo_impresszum.htm ''Origo Constantini. Nagy Constantinus császár eredete''] (in Latin-Hungarian). * [http://www.constantinethegreatcoins.com/Constantine/Origo.html ''Origo Constantini Imperatoris''] (in English). * [http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/valesianus2.html The Latin Library. ''Anonymus Valesianus Pars Posterior: Chronica Theodericiana]'' (in Latin). * [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Excerpta_Valesiana/home.html LacusCurtius: Anonymous Valesianus] (English and Latin text with notes and commentary).
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2017}} {{More citations needed|date=April 2015}} '''Austin M. Woodbury''' (1899 near Spencer, in the [[Hawkesbury River|Hawkesbury]] Valley of [[New South Wales]] – 1979) was an [[Australian]] [[Catholic]] [[philosopher]].
==Biography== Woodbury joined the [[Society of Mary (Marists)|Marist Fathers]] and gained a doctorate in Rome, studying under the [[Scholasticism|scholastic]] philosopher [[Reginald Garrigou-Lagrange]]. In 1945, he founded the Aquinas Academy in [[Sydney]], a school of philosophy aimed mainly at lay people. He headed the Academy until 1975, teaching a strictly scholastic philosophy based on the teaching of [[Thomas Aquinas]]. A combative personality, he was often in conflict with the [[atheist]] Professor of Philosophy at the [[University of Sydney]], [[John Anderson (philosopher)|John Anderson]], whom Austin believed was corrupting Sydney's youth. Woodbury died in 1979.
The Aquinas Academy:
The Aquinas Academy was set up under the auspices of the Australian Province of the Marist Fathers by Fr Austin Woodbury SM in March 1945. The Academy began as a centre for the study of Philosophy and Theology in the Thomistic tradition. For some twenty-nine years it continued in this capacity under Fr Woodbury's guidance, in premises at the back of St Patrick's Church, Gloucester Street, in The Rocks (Sydney, NSW). For a short while the Academy offered a License in Philosophy under accreditation from the University of St Thomas in Rome. Since its inception, a number of qualified priests, religious and laity have been part of the lecturing staff. The Academy was one of the pioneers of Catholic adult education in Australia.
Since 1975, the Academy has increasingly focused on general adult education in the faith. Perhaps the most popular of the programs mounted was the Christian Growth Program, offering basic education in theology, morality, psychology and spirituality. During this time the Academy also developed a State-accredited program for religious education teachers, offering a Certificate in Religious Studies. In these years, also, a wide array of seminars, special lecture series, summer schools and workshops were offered – with presenters from Australia and overseas. All these programs were designed to contribute in some way to adult education in the faith. One of the features of the Academy during these latter years has been its mobility – programs have been offered at various centres in and around Sydney and along the eastern seaboard.
Former Principals, Fr Kevin Bates SM and Fr John Thornhill SM with one of the Students to graduate with a Licentiate from the University of St Thomas through the Aquinas Academy, Sr Celestine Pooley RSM Following the major renovations to the St Patrick’s Church and the surrounding buildings (1998-2001), the Aquinas Academy is now housed on the third and fourth floors – Levels 5 and 7 – of the building at 141 Harrington Street that for many years was St Patrick's Business College. The first and second floors of that same building are used for parish meeting rooms and offices.
Aquinas Academy continues a significant commitment to adult education in the faith, still under the auspices of the Australian Province of the Marist Fathers. Together with the Marists, a number of other priests, religious and laity continue to serve the community through the Academy. Aquinas Academy today continues its commitment to adult education within the Catholic tradition to assist people seeking to develop a mature faith. Situated in Sydney's central business district, the Academy aims most particularly to become a school of spirituality in the heart of the city.
Fr Michael Whelan SM is currently the Director of the Academy. Sr Marie Biddle RSJ is a Lecturer and Coordinator of the Spirituality Program. There are a number of other visiting and occasional Lecturers and Presenters of various programs, from Australia and overseas.
==References== *J. Franklin, (2003), ''Corrupting the Youth: A History of Philosophy in Australia'', [[Macleay Press]], ch. 4. *J. Thorpe, (2016), ''The Aquinas Academy 1945-2015: A Very Personal Story'', ATF Press.
==External links== *[http://www.cts.org.au Website of the Centre for Thomistic Studies], successor of the Aquinas Academy.
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Woodbury, Austin}} [[Category:Australian philosophers]] [[Category:Roman Catholic philosophers]] [[Category:Thomist philosophers]] [[Category:Australian Roman Catholic priests]] [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} A '''blast valve''' is used to protect a shelter, such as a [[fallout shelter]] or [[bunker]], from the effects of sudden outside air pressure changes. A [[nuclear weapon]] creates a shock wave, which may produce sudden pressure changes of more than an atmosphere (about 1 bar or 15 pounds per square inch) even several kilometers or miles from the detonation point. After the shock wave passes, a sudden negative pressure follows.
If such pressure waves enter a shelter, they will likely do substantial harm to occupants and equipment. A blast valve is placed in air intake/exhaust pipes, that remains open normally, but automatically closes when strong pressure is applied in either direction. [[Blast damper]]s operate in the same fashion and are related or identical to blast valves, the former name however is generally used to describe blast mitigation devices, for more, [[conventional explosive]] events.
A typical blast valve has entries of 150–300 mm diameter (6-12"), and a larger center section. Within the center section is a disk mounted on an axle, with weak springs that keep it centered, away from both entries. Pressure displaces the disk along the axle, until it plugs one entry or the other. After the blast, the springs return the disk to the center, re-opening the valve.
Another type of blast valve employs rounded metal tubes held in place by springs. As pressure rises it pushes the tubes against the frame of the valve closing the opening. These valves are typically unidirectional in airflow and are employed in large wall structures where large amounts of airflow is required.
One form of blast valve, popularized by the book [[Nuclear War Survival Skills]] and tested by [[ORNL]] is worn flat rubber [[tire]] treads nailed or bolted to frames strong enough to resist the maximum overpressure, with tested closing times cited as being identical to commercial grade blast valves, however the use of this form of blast valve design must also take the risk of the flammable rubber catching fire into consideration.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oism.org/nwss/s73p939.htm |title=App. D: Expedient Blast Shelters |publisher=Arnold Jagt |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
<gallery> Image:TEMET_PSV_Blast_Valve.jpg|High pressure PSV Blast Valve protects to 60bar (~870psi) peak reflected overpressure. Image:TEMET_PV_KK_Blast_Valve.jpg|PV-KK Blast Valve used to protect against peak reflected overpressures up to 15bars (215psi). Image:TEMET_PV_KK_Blast_Valves_Em.jpg|PV-KK Blast Valves embedded in massive concrete walls of a hardened shelter / bunker. File:NNSA-NSO-574.jpg|Hollow steel ball serving as a blast valve for the ventilating system of a hardened shelter. </gallery>
{{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blast Valve}} [[Category:Valves]] [[Category:Nuclear warfare]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{No footnotes|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Charles K. Bliss | birth_name = Karl Kasiel Blitz | birth_date = 1897 | birth_place = [[Chernivtsi]], [[Austria-Hungary]] | death_date = 1985 | alma_mater = [[Vienna University of Technology]] | occupation = chemical engineer, semiotician | known_for = Inventor of [[Blissymbolics]] | citizenship = [[Ukraine]]
Australia }} '''Charles K. Bliss''' (1897–1985) was a chemical engineer and [[semiotics|semiotician]], and the inventor of [[Blissymbolics]]. He was born in the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]], and later gained [[Australia]]n citizenship. ==Early life== Bliss was born '''Karl Kasiel Blitz''', the eldest of four children to Michel Anchel and Jeanette Blitz, in [[Chernivtsi]] in the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] (current [[Ukraine]]). The family were impoverished and the senior Blitz supported the family as an [[optician]], [[mechanic]], and [[lathe (tool)|wood turner]]. Later on Bliss said that the symbols on his father's [[circuit diagram]]s made instant sense to him. They were a "logical language". He was similarly impressed by [[chemical symbols]], which he thought could be read by anyone, regardless of their [[first language|mother tongue]]. Bliss's early life was difficult. It was cold and his family were poor and hungry. Because the family was [[Jewish]], he suffered [[anti-Semitic]] taunts. When Bliss was eight years old, Russia lost the [[Russo-Japanese War]], Russian [[pogrom]]s against the Jews accelerated, and refugees came into Bliss's town from the nearby Russian town of [[Chişinău|Kishinev]]. Also in 1905 Bliss saw a slide show of the [[Austro-Hungarian North Pole Expedition]] of [[Karl Weyprecht|Weyprecht]] and [[Julius von Payer|Payer]]. It inspired him to study engineering to improve technology for ordinary people. ==Detention and Second World War== Bliss graduated from the [[Vienna University of Technology]] as a [[chemical engineer]] in 1922. He joined Telefunken, a German television and radio apparatus company, and rose to be chief of the patent department. In March 1938, the [[Third Reich]] annexed [[Austria]] via the [[Anschluss]], and Bliss, as a Jew, was sent to [[Dachau concentration camp]]. Later. he was moved to [[Buchenwald concentration camp]]. His wife, Claire, a German [[Roman Catholicism|Catholic]], made constant efforts to have him released. He was released but was required to leave the country for [[England]] immediately. In England, Bliss tried to bring his wife to him, but the outbreak of [[World War II]] in September 1939 made that impossible. It was there that, because the Nazi bombing of England was called the "blitz," he changed his surname to Bliss. Bliss arranged for Claire to escape Germany via his family in Czernowitz, [[Romania]] (now called [[Chernivtsi]] and in the [[Ukraine]]). Needing to leave there, Claire moved on to [[Greece]] and safety, until October 1940 when [[Italy]] invaded Greece. The couple were reunited on Christmas Eve 1940, after Claire continued east to [[Shanghai]] and Charles went west to Shanghai via [[Canada]] and [[Japan]]. After the Japanese occupied Shanghai, Bliss and his wife were placed into the [[Hongkew ghetto]]. Claire, as a German and a Christian had the option of claiming her German citizenship, applying for a divorce and being released. She did not do so but accompanied Bliss into the ghetto. In Shanghai, Bliss became interested in [[Chinese characters]], which he mistakenly thought were [[ideogram]]s. He studied them and learned how to read shop signs and Chinese newspapers. With some astonishment, he one day realised that he had been reading the symbols off not in Chinese, but in his own language, German. With ideograms for his inspiration, Bliss set out to develop a system of writing by pictures. At that time Bliss had not become aware of [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]]'s "[[characteristica universalis|Universal Symbolism]]". ==Australia== Bliss and his wife migrated to [[Australia]] after the war, reaching Australia in July 1946. His semiotic ideas met with universal rejection. Bliss, without any Australian or [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] qualifications had to work as a [[manual labour|labourer]] to support his family. He worked on his system of symbols at night. Bliss and his wife became Australian citizens. Originally Bliss had called his system "World Writing" because the aim was to establish a series of symbols that would be understood by all, regardless of language. Bliss then decided an English-language name was too restricted and called the system Semantography. In Sydney in 1949 Bliss published the three-volume ''International Semantography: A non-alphabetical Symbol Writing readable in all languages''. There was no great positive reaction. For the next four years Claire Bliss sent 6,000 letters to educators and universities, to no better effect. Bliss's wife died in 1961 after years of ill health. In 1965 Bliss published a second edition of his work, ''Semantography (Blissymbolics)''. ==Partial success== It was about this time that the increase in international tourism convinced many that only a pictorial symbol language could be understood by all. Bliss made sure his idea was attached to his name, hence Blissymbolics. In 1971, Bliss learned that since 1965, a particular centre in Canada had been using his symbols to teach children with [[cerebral palsy]] to communicate. He was thrilled at first, but he became horrified when he learned that the center had extended his set of symbols and was using the symbols as a bridge to help the children learn to use spoken and written words in a traditional language, which were far from his vision for Blissymbolics. He badgered and eventually sued the center, at one time even threatening a nurse with imprisonment. After ten years of constant attacks from Bliss, the center came to a compromise with Bliss because it felt the publicity he drew to be bringing a bad name to the center. The world copyright for use of his symbols with handicapped children was licensed to the Blissymbolics Communication Foundation in Canada. ==Recognition== Bliss was made a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] (A.M.) in 1976 for "services to the community, particularly to handicapped children".[https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/131822763 Awards in Order of Australia, ''The Canberra Times'', (Saturday, 12 June 1976)< p8.] On the basis of the recognition of the innovative nature of his work, Bliss was appointed an Honorary Fellow in Linguistics at the [[Australian National University]], by the (then) Head of the ANU School of Linguistics, [[R. M. W. Dixon|Professor Bob Dixon]], in 1979.[https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/110937602 'Symbol Man' an ANU Fellow, ''The Canberra Times'', (Thursday, 29 March 1979), p.10.] ==See also== * [[Blissymbols]] ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==Publications== ===Bliss=== *Bliss, C.K., ''International Semantography: A Non-Alphabetical Symbol Writing Readable in All Languages. A Practical Tool for General International Communication, Especially in Science, Industry, Commerce, Traffic, etc. and for Semantical Education, Based on the Principles of Ideographic Writing and Chemical Symbolism'', Institute of Semantography, (Sydney), 1949. *Bliss, C.K., ''Semantography-Blissymbolics: A Simple System of 100 Logical Pictorial Symbols, Which can be Operated and Read Like 1+2=3 in All Languages... (Third, Enlarged Edition)'', Semantography-Blissymbolics Pubs, (Sydney), 1978. *Bliss, C.K., ''Semantography and the Ultimate Meanings of Mankind: Report and Reflections on a Meeting of the Author with Julian Huxley. A selection of the Semantography Series; with "What scientists think of C.K. Bliss' semantography"'', Institute for Semantography, (Sydney), 1955. *Bliss, C.K., ''The Blissymbols Picture Book (Three Volumes)'', Development and Advisory Publications of N.S.W. for Semantography-Blissymbols, (Coogee), 1985. *Bliss, C.K., ''The Story of the Struggle for Semantography: The Semantography Series, Nos.1–163, Institute for Semantography, (Coogee), 1942–1956. *Bliss, C.K. & McNaughton, S., ''Mr Symbol Man: The Book to the Film Produced by the National Film Board of Canada and Film Australia (Second Edition)'', Semantography (Blissymbolics) Publications, (Sydney), 1976. *Bliss, C.K. (& Frederick, M.A. illus.), ''The Invention and Discovery That Will Change Our Lives'', Semantography-Blissymbolics Publications, (Sydney), 1970. ===Others=== *Breckon, C.J., "Symbolism as a Written Language", pp.74–83 in Breckon, C.J., ''Graphic Symbolism'', McGraw-Hill, Sydney), 1975. *Reiser, O.L., ''Unified symbolism for world understanding in science: including Bliss symbols (Semantography) and logic, cybernetics and semantics: A paper read in parts at the Annual Meeting of the AmericanAssociation for the Advancement of Science, Philadelphia, 1951, and at the Conference of the InternationalSociety of Significa, Amsterdam, 1953'', Semantography Publishing Co., (Coogee), 1955. ==External links== *{{imdb title|0202481|Mr. Symbol Man (1974)}} *[http://www.radiolab.org/2012/dec/17/man-became-bliss/ Mr. Bliss], RadioLab Podcast, accessed 24 December 2012 *[http://www.blissymbolics.us/biography/ "Biography of C. K. Bliss"] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bliss, Charles K}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to Australia]] [[Category:Linguists from Australia]] [[Category:Semioticians]] [[Category:Creators of writing systems]] [[Category:Australian Jews]] [[Category:Australian inventors]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Australia]] [[Category:Jewish inventors]] [[Category:Vienna University of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Dachau concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Buchenwald concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Holocaust survivors]] [[Category:Nazi-era ghetto inmates]] [[Category:Constructed language creators]]

page.title: Chronological summary of the 2016 Summer Olympics

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 21 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}}{{2016 Summer Olympics}} This is a chronological summary of the major events of the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. The first matches in the group stages of the [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football events]] were played on Wednesday 3 August. The [[2016 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony]] took place on Friday 5 August. The last day of competition and the [[2016 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]] was on Sunday 21 August. With 306 sets of medals, the games featured 28 [[Olympic sports]], including [[rugby sevens]] and [[golf]], which were added to the Olympic program in 2009. These sporting events took place at 33 venues in the host city, and at five in [[São Paulo]], [[Belo Horizonte]], [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]], [[Brasília]], and [[Manaus]]. Due to the [[European migrant crisis]] and other reasons, the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) allowed athletes to compete under the [[Olympic Flag]] as part of the "[[Refugee Olympic Team at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Refugee Olympic Team]]" (ROT); out of 43 refugee athletes deemed potentially eligible, 10 were chosen to form this team.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/olympics/35710578 |title=Rio 2016: Refugee team to compete at Olympics |accessdate=3 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}} Due to the suspension of the National Olympic Committee of Kuwait, participants from Kuwait were allowed to participate under the Olympic Flag as "[[Independent Olympic Athletes at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Independent Olympic Athletes]]" (IOA).{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/jul/01/russian-whistleblower-yulia-stepanova-cleared-neutral-athlete-rio|title=Russian whistleblower Yuliya Stepanova to compete as ‘neutral athlete’ in Rio|website=The Guardian|accessdate=15 July 2016}} == Calendar == {{2016 Summer Olympics calendar}} ==Medal table== {{Main|2016 Summer Olympics medal table}} {{:2016 Summer Olympics medal table}} Brazil was ranked 13th. See the complete medals table at [[2016 Summer Olympics medal table]]. ==Day (−2) — Wednesday 3 August== {{Collapse top|3 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} ;[[File:Football pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football]] * The first competitions of the Games took place. The first matches in the group stage of the [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]] were played.{{cite web|title=Circular no. 1383 – Olympic Football Tournaments Rio 2016 – Men's and Women's Tournaments|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/02/18/91/39/circularno.1383-olympicfootballtournamentsrio2016-mensandwomenstournaments_neutral.pdf|publisher=FIFA.com|accessdate=2 October 2013|date=1 October 2013}} {{Collapse bottom}} ==Day (−1) — Thursday 4 August== {{Collapse top|4 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} ;[[File:Football pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football]] * The first matches in the group stage of the [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] were held. {{Collapse bottom}} ==Day 0 — Friday 5 August== {{Collapse top|5 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} ;Off-field update * Boxer [[Hassan Saada]] ([[Morocco at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Morocco]]) was arrested over allegations of sexual assault. He was detained for 15 days, pending an investigation, which will prevent him from competing in any [[Boxing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|boxing events]].{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36989897 | title=Moroccan boxer held over alleged sex assault | publisher=BBC | date=5 August 2016 | accessdate=5 August 2016}} ;[[File:Archery pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Archery]] * The ranking round in both the [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's individual|men's individual competition]] and the [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's individual|women's individual competition]] took place. ;[[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2016 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|Opening ceremony]] * The opening ceremony was held at [[Maracanã Stadium]] at 20:00 [[Time in Brazil|BRT]] ([[UTC−3]]).{{cite web|url=http://ingressos.rio2016.com/rio2016.htm?token=9C19AE920555F7A1497BC9AD742F04E9&action=filter&doc=search&fun=registration&affiliate=OGR&language=en|date=31 March 2015|accessdate=14 June 2015|title=Tickets|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150616065718/http://ingressos.rio2016.com/rio2016.htm?token=9C19AE920555F7A1497BC9AD742F04E9&action=filter&doc=search&fun=registration&affiliate=OGR&language=en|archivedate=16 June 2015|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetorch/2016/08/05/488732992/rio-throws-a-party-for-the-world-kicking-off-the-2016-olympics|title=Rio Throws A Party For The World, Kicking Off The 2016 Olympics|access-date=6 August 2016}} [[Vanderlei Cordeiro de Lima]], marathon bronze medalist at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]], lit the [[Olympic cauldron]]. Soccer legend [[Pelé]], who was widely rumored to be the first choice to light it, was unable to attend for health reasons.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/08/05/sports/olympics/ap-oly-rio-opening-ceremony-the-latest.html?_r=0 | title=The Latest: De Lima Lights the Olympic Cauldron | agency=Associated Press | newspaper=New York Times | date=5 August 2016 | accessdate=5 August 2016 }} {{Collapse bottom}} == Day 1 — Saturday 6 August == ===Detailed results (day 1)=== {{Collapse top|6 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Archery pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Archery]] * [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's First day of the Group stage * [[Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: First day of the Group stage ;[[File:Boxing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Boxing [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's individual road race|men's individual road race]], [[Greg Van Avermaet]] of Belgium won the gold medal with a time of {{nowrap|6h 10' 05"}}. [[Jakob Fuglsang]] of Denmark finished close behind to win the silver, and [[Rafał Majka]] was five seconds behind to earn the bronze. ;[[File:Equestrian pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] * [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Individual eventing|Individual eventing]]: Dressage round * [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Team eventing|Team eventing]]: Dressage round ;[[File:Fencing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Fencing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Fencing]] * [[Fencing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's épée|Women's épée]]: ** Semifinal no. 1: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Rossella Fiamingo]]|ITA|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Sun Yiwen]]|CHN|2016 Summer}}, 12–11 ** Semifinal no. 2: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Emese Szász]]|HUN|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Lauren Rembi]]|FRA|2016 Summer}}, 10–6 ** Bronze Medal Match: {{bronze3}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Sun Yiwen]]|CHN|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Lauren Rembi]]|FRA|2016 Summer}}, 15–13 ** Gold Medal Match: {{gold1}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Emese Szász]]|HUN|2016 Summer}} defeated {{silver2}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Rossella Fiamingo]]|ITA|2016 Summer}}, 15–13 ;[[File:Field hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Field hockey]] * [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]]: First day of the Group stage * [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: First day of the Group stage ;[[File:Football pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football]] * This was the second day of the group stage in the [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]]. ;[[File:Gymnastics_(artistic)_pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Gymnastics (artistic)]] * The [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's artistic qualification|men's artistic qualification rounds]] took place. During the vault rotation, France's [[Samir Aït Saïd]] suffered a serious injury when his left leg snapped on landing.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/rio-2016/2016/08/06/french-gymnast-samir-ait-said-scary-injury-vault/88337384/|title=Scary injury: French gymnast Samir Ait Said snaps his leg on vault|last=Armour|first=Nancy|publisher=USA Today|date=6 August 2016|access-date=7 August 2016}} ;[[File:Handball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Handball]] * The first day of the group stage in the [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]]. ;[[File:Judo pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Judo at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Judo]] * [[Judo at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 60 kg|Men's 60 kg (extra-lightweight)]] ** Semi-final no. 1: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Beslan Mudranov]]|RUS|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Amiran Papinashvili]]|GEO|2016 Summer}} ** Semi-final no. 2: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Yeldos Smetov]]|KAZ|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Orkhan Safarov]]|AZE|2016 Summer}} ** Bronze Medal Match no. 1: {{bronze3}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Naohisa Takato]]|JPN|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Orkhan Safarov]]|AZE|2016 Summer}} ** Bronze Medal Match no. 2: {{bronze3}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Diyorbek Urozboev]]|UZB|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Amiran Papinashvili]]|GEO|2016 Summer}} ** Gold Medal Match: {{gold1}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Beslan Mudranov]]|RUS|2016 Summer}} defeated {{silver2}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Yeldos Smetov]]|KAZ|2016 Summer}} * [[Judo at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 48 kg|Women's 48 kg (extra-lightweight)]]: ** Semi-final no. 1: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Jeong Bo-kyeong]]|KOR|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Dayaris Mestre]]|CUB|2016 Summer}} ** Semi-final no. 2: {{flagIOCathlete|[[Paula Pareto]]|ARG|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Ami Kondo]]|JPN|2016 Summer}} ** Bronze Medal Match no. 1: {{bronze3}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Ami Kondo]]|JPN|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Mönkhbatyn Urantsetseg]]|MGL|2016 Summer}} ** Bronze Medal Match no. 2: {{bronze3}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Galbadrakhyn Otgontsetseg]]|KAZ|2016 Summer}} defeated {{flagIOCathlete|[[Dayaris Mestre]]|CUB|2016 Summer}} ** Gold Medal Match: {{gold1}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Paula Pareto]]|ARG|2016 Summer}} defeated {{silver2}} {{flagIOCathlete|[[Jeong Bo-kyeong]]|KOR|2016 Summer}} ;[[File:Rowing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Rowing]] * This was the first day of the heats round in eight of the 14 rowing events. ;[[File:Rugby union pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Rugby sevens at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Rugby sevens]] * This was the first day of the pool stage in the [[Rugby sevens at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's tournament]]. ;[[File:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] * In the [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 10 metre air pistol|men's 10 m air pistol]], [[Hoàng Xuân Vinh]] of Vietnam recorded 202.5 points to win the gold medal edging out [[Felipe Almeida Wu]] of Brazil by 0.4 points. [[Pang Wei]] (China) won the bronze with 180.4 points. This is also Vietnam's first ever gold medal in any Olympic event. * In the [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 10 metre air rifle|women's 10 m air rifle]], [[Virginia Thrasher]] (USA) won the gold medal with 208 points.{{cite news|title=Virginia Thrasher wins first gold medal of Rio Olympics for USA in 10m air rifle|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/aug/06/virginia-thrasher-first-gold-rio-2016-olympics-air-rifle|accessdate=6 August 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=6 August 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://results.nbcolympics.com/shooting/event/women-10m-air-rifle/index.html|title=Rio 2016 Olympic Games – Shooting – Women's Air Rifle 10m|website=NBCOlympics.com|access-date=6 August 2016}} [[Du Li]] (China) scored 207 points to win silver and defending Olympic champion [[Yi Siling]] (China) scored 185.4 points to win the bronze. ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metre freestyle|Men's 400 m freestyle]]: [[Mack Horton]] (Australia) finished at 3:41.55 to earn the gold medal, defending Olympic champion [[Sun Yang]] (China) finished at 3:41.68 to win the silver, and [[Gabriele Detti]] (Italy) won the bronze with a time of 3:43.49. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metre individual medley|Men's 400 m individual medley]]: Japan's [[Kosuke Hagino]] earned the gold medal with a time of 4:06.05, [[Chase Kalisz]] of the United States recorded a time of 4:06.75 to win silver, and Japan's [[Daiya Seto]] won the bronze with a time of 4:09.71. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metre individual medley|Women's 400 m individual medley]]: Hungary's [[Katinka Hosszú]] set a world record of 4:26.36 to finish with the gold, the United States's [[Maya DiRado]] finished with the silver with a time of 4:31.15, and Spain's [[Mireia Belmonte]] recorded 4:32.39 to win the bronze. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 100 metre freestyle relay|Women's 4 × 100 m freestyle relay]]: The Australian team of [[Emma McKeon]], [[Brittany Elmslie]], [[Bronte Campbell]], [[Cate Campbell]] set a new world record with a time of 3:30.65 to win gold. Team USA ([[Simone Manuel]], [[Abbey Weitzeil]], [[Dana Vollmer]], [[Katie Ledecky]]) finished with silver with a time of 3:31.89 setting a new American record. Team Canada ([[Sandrine Mainville]], [[Chantal Van Landeghem]], [[Taylor Ruck]], [[Penny Oleksiak]]) recorded a time of 3:32.89 to win the bronze also setting a new national record. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * The first day of the preliminary rounds in both the [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] and the [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] were held. ;[[File:Tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Tennis]] * This was the first day of the round of 64 in both the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Singles|men's singles]] and the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's Singles|women's singles]], and the round of 32 in the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Doubles|men's doubles]] and the [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's Doubles|women's doubles]]. ;[[File:Volleyball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Volleyball (indoor)]] * [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's indoor]]: Group stage ;[[File:Volleyball (beach) pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Volleyball (beach)]] * [[Beach volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's beach]]: Group stage * [[Beach volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's beach]]: Group stage ;[[File:Water polo pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Water polo at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Water polo]] * The group stage in the [[Water polo at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's tournament]] began:{{cite web|url=http://results.nbcolympics.com/water-polo/event/men/index.html|title=Rio 2016 Olympic Games – Water Polo – Men|website=results.nbcolympics.com|access-date=6 August 2016}} ;[[File:Weightlifting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]] * In the [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 48 kg|women's 48 kg]], Thailand's [[Sopita Tanasan]] won the gold with a score of 200, Indonesia's [[Sri Wahyuni Agustiani]] earned a score of 192 to win the silver, and Japan's [[Hiromi Miyake]] won the bronze with a score of 188. {{div col end}} {{Collapse bottom}} ===Summary table (day 1)=== {{Collapse top|6 August 2016 — summary table|bg=gold}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Sport ! Summer Olympics – Women's tournament#Quarterfinals|Women's tournament quarterfinals]]: ** '''{{ru7w-rt|AUS}} 24'''–0 {{ru7w|ESP}} ** '''{{ru7w-rt|CAN}} 15'''–5 {{ru7w|FRA}} ** '''{{ru7w-rt|GBR}} 26'''–7 {{ru7w|FIJ}} ** '''{{ru7w-rt|NZL}} 5'''–0 {{ru7w|USA}} ;[[File:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 10 metre air pistol|Women's 10 metre air pistol]]: [[Zhang Mengxue]] (China) recorded an Olympic record of 199.4 to win the gold, [[Vitalina Batsarashkina]] (Russia) won the silver with a score of 197.1, and [[Anna Korakaki]] (Greece) won the bronze with 177.7. * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's trap|Women's trap]]: In the Gold Medal Match, [[Catherine Skinner]] (Australia) finished with a score of 12 to win the gold, and [[Natalie Rooney]] (New Zealand) finished with the silver with 11. [[Corey Cogdell]] (United States) won a shoot-off over [[Fátima Gálvez]] (Spain) to earn the bronze. ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre breaststroke|Men's 100 m breaststroke]]: In the final race, [[Adam Peaty]] (Great Britain) recorded a world record of 57.13 to win the gold. [[Cameron van der Burgh]] (South Africa) win the silver with a time of 58.69, and [[Cody Miller]] (USA) finished with the bronze at 58.87. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metre freestyle relay|Men's 4 × 100 m freestyle relay]]: In the final race, Team USA finished with a time of 3:09.92 to win the gold. For [[Michael Phelps]] this was a record 19th Olympic gold medal. France finished with the silver with a time of 3:10.53, and Australia finished with the bronze with 3:11.37. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metre freestyle|Women's 400 m freestyle]]: The final race saw [[Katie Ledecky]] (USA) break a world record with a time of 3:56.46 to win the gold. The silver went to [[Jazmin Carlin]] (Great Britain), who recorded a time of 4:01.23, and [[Leah Smith (swimmer)|Leah Smith]] (USA) won the bronze with 4:01.92. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre butterfly|Women's 100 m butterfly]]: In the final, [[Sarah Sjöström]] (Sweden) finished with 55.48 to record a gold medal, a world record, and an Olympic record. [[Penny Oleksiak]] (Canada) finished with the silver with 56.46, and [[Dana Vollmer]] (USA) won the bronze with 56.63. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|Men's singles]]: Second round * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|Women's singles]]: Second round ;[[File:Tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Tennis]] * [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Singles|Men's Singles]]: Round of 64 * [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's Singles|Women's Singles]]: Round of 64 * [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Doubles|Men's Doubles]]: Round of 32 * [[Tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's Doubles|Women's Doubles]]; Round of 32 ;[[File:Volleyball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Volleyball (indoor)]] * [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's indoor tournament]]: First day of the Preliminary stage ;[[File:Volleyball (beach) pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Volleyball (beach)]] * [[Beach volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's beach tournament]]: Second day of the Preliminary stage * [[Beach volleyball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's beach tournament]]: Second day of the Preliminary stage ;[[File:Weightlifting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]] * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 56 kg|Men's 56 kg]]: China's [[Long Qingquan]] won the Gold, setting an Olympic record of lifting 170 kg in the Clean&Jerk, and a world record of a total score of 307 kg. [[Om Yun-chol]] (North Korea) finished with a total score of 303 kg to win the silver, and the bronze went to [[Sinphet Kruaithong]] (Thailand) after recording a total score of 289 kg. * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 53 kg|Women's 53 kg]]: China's [[Li Yajun (weightlifter)|Li Yajun]] set a new Olympic record in Snatch after lifting 101 kg but she was unable to lift her three Clean&Jerk attempts. The gold instead went to [[Hsu Shu-ching]] (Chinese Taipei), who finished with a score of 212 kg. The silver went to [[Hidilyn Diaz]] (Philippines) with a score of 200 kg, and [[Yoon Jin-hee]] (South Korea) finished with a score of 199 kg to win the bronze. {{div col end}} {{Collapse bottom}} ===Summary table (day 2)=== {{Collapse top|7 August 2016 — summary table|bg=gold}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Sport ! rowspan="2" | Event ! colspan="3" | Gold medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Silver medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Bronze medalist(s) ! rowspan="2" | {{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} |- | [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Archery]] | [[Archery at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's team|Women's team]] | [[Chang Hye-jin]]

;[[File:Sailing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Sailing]] * The first day of the Round Robin rounds in the [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser|Laser]], [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser Radial|Laser Radial]], [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's RS:X|Men's RS:X]], and [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's RS:X|Women's RS:X]]. ;[[File:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] * In the final round of the [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 10 metre air rifle|Men's 10 m air rifle]], [[Niccolò Campriani]] (Italy) set an Olympic record of 206.1 to win the gold. [[Serhiy Kulish]] (Ukraine) won the silver with 204.6, and [[Vladimir Maslennikov]] (Russia) won the bronze with 184.2. * In the final round of the [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's trap|men's trap]], the Gold Medal Match went into a shoot-off: [[Josip Glasnović]] (Croatia) came out ahead to win the gold, and [[Giovanni Pellielo]] (Italy) won the silver. Meanwhile, [[Edward Ling]] (Great Britain) defeated [[David Kostelecký]] (Czech Republic) in the Bronze Medal Match. ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metre freestyle|Men's 200 m freestyle]]: [[Sun Yang]] (China) finished the final race with a time of 1:44.65 to win the gold, [[Chad le Clos]] (South Africa) finished at 1:45.20 to win the silver, and [[Conor Dwyer]] (USA) won the bronze with a time of 1:45.23. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre backstroke|Men's 100 m backstroke]]: In the final, [[Ryan Murphy (swimmer)|Ryan Murphy]] (USA) set an Olympic record of 51.97 to win the gold, [[Xu Jiayu]] (China) finished at 52.31 to win the silver, and [[David Plummer (swimmer)|David Plummer]] (USA) won the bronze with a time of 52.40. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre backstroke|Women's 100 m backstroke]]: [[Katinka Hosszú]] (Hungary) won the gold with a time of 58.45 in the final. [[Kathleen Baker]] (USA) won the silver with a time of 58.75. [[Kylie Masse]] (Canada) and [[Fu Yuanhui]] (China) tied for third place with a time of 58.76, and thus were each awarded bronze medals. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre breaststroke|Women's 100 m breaststroke]]: [[Lilly King]] (USA) won the gold with an Olympic record of 1:04.93 in the final. [[Yuliya Yefimova]] (Russia) won the silver with a time of 1:05.50, and [[Katie Meili]] (USA) won the bronze with 1:05.69. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the Figueroa (weightlifter)|Óscar Figueroa]] (Colombia) won the gold with a final score of 318, [[Eko Yuli Irawan]] (Indonesia) finished with the silver with a score of 312, and [[Farkhad Kharki]] (Kazakhstan) finished at 305 to win the bronze. * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 58 kg|Women's 58 kg]]: Thailand's [[Sukanya Srisurat]] won gold with a total score of 240, after setting a new Olympic record after lifting 110 kg in Snatch. ;[[File:Canoeing (slalom) pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Canoeing (slalom)]] * In the final race in the [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's slalom C-1|men's slalom C-1]], [[Denis Gargaud Chanut]] (France) won the gold with a time of 94.17, [[Matej Benus]] (Slovakia) finished with the silver with a time of 95.02, and [[Takuya Haneda]] (Japan) finished at 97.44 to win the bronze. ;[[File:Diving pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Diving]] * The gold medal in the [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's synchronized 10 metre platform|women's synchronized 10 metre platform]] went to China ([[Chen Ruolin]] and [[Liu Huixia]]) with a score of 354.00. Malaysia ([[Cheong Jun Hoong]] and [[Pandelela Rinong]]) finished at 344.34 to win the silver, and Canada ([[Meaghan Benfeito]] and [[Roseline Filion]]) won the bronze with a score of 336.18. ;[[File:Equestrian pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] * [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Individual eventing|Individual eventing]]: [[Michael Jung (equestrian)|Michael Jung]] (Germany) finished with the lowest total score of 40.90 to win the gold, [[Astier Nicolas]] (France) finished with the silver with a total score of 48.00, and [[Phillip Dutton]] (United States) finished at 51.80 to win the bronze. * [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Team eventing|Team eventing]]: France finished with the lowest total score of 169.00 to win the gold. Germany won the silver with a score of 172.80, and Australia finished at 175.30 to with the bronze. ;[[File:Fencing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Fencing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Fencing]] * (United States) finished the final race with a time of 1:53.36 to win gold, beating [[Masato Sakai (swimmer)|Masato Sakai]] (Japan), who finished with a time of 1:53.40 to win the silver, and [[Tamás Kenderesi]] (Hungary), who finished with the bronze at 1:53.62. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 200 metre freestyle relay|Men's 4 × 200 m freestyle relay]]: Team USA won the final race and the gold with a time of 7:00.66, Great Britain was second and received the silver with 7:03.13, and Japan was third with 7:03.50. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metre freestyle|Women's 200 metre freestyle]]: Finishing the final race at 1:53.73, [[Katie Ledecky]] (United States) won the gold. [[Sarah Sjöström]] finished with the silver at 1:54.08, and [[Emma McKeon]] (Australia) finished at 1:54.92 to win the bronze. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metre individual medley|Women's 200 metre individual medley]]: Hungary's [[Katinka Hosszú]] recorded an Olympic record of 2:06.58 in the final race to win the gold, beating Great Britain's [[Siobhan-Marie O'Connor]] time of 2:06.88. [[Maya DiRado]] (USA) finished in third at 2:08.79. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Weightlifting]] * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 69 kg|Men's 69 kg]]: [[Shi Zhiyong (weightlifter, born 1993)|Shi Zhiyong]] of China finished with a total score of 352 kg to win the gold, beating Turkey's [[Daniyar Ismayilov]]'s total final score of 351 kg. Kyrgyzstan's [[Izzat Artykov]] was initially awarded the bronze with a final score of 339 kg, but was later disqualified after he tested positive for [[strychnine]].{{cite news|title=Rio Olympics 2016: Izzat Artykov stripped of weightlifting bronze|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/37122892|accessdate=18 August 2016|publisher=BBC News|date=18 August 2016}} On 18 August, the bronze was then the awarded to Colombia's [[Luis Javier Mosquera]], who finished after Artykov at 338 kg. * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 63 kg|Women's 63 kg]]: China's [[Deng Wei (weightlifter)|Deng Wei]] set a world record of 147 kg in the Clean & Jerk, and another world record for a total score of 262 kg, to win the gold. [[Peter Kauzer]] of Slovenia won the silver with a time of 88.70, and [[Jiří Prskavec (canoeist, born 1993)|Jiří Prskavec]] of the Czech Republic finished at 88.99 to win the bronze. ;[[File:Cycling Cancellara]] of Switzerland won the gold with a time of 1:12:15.42, Dutchman [[Tom Dumoulin]] won silver with a time of 1:13:02.83, and [[Chris Froome]] of Great Britain finished at 1:13:17.54 to win bronze.{{cite web|url=https://www.rio2016.com/en/cycling-road-mens-individual-time-trial |title=Cycling Road: Men's Individual Time Trial |date= |publisher=Rio2016 |access-date=15 August 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's road time trial|Women's road time trial]]: American [[Kristin Armstrong]] recorded a time of 44:26.42 to win gold, while [[Olga Zabelinskaya]] of Russia won silver with a time of 44:31.97. [[Anna van der Breggen]] of the Netherlands won bronze with a time of 44:37.80.{{cite web|url=https://www.rio2016.com/en/cycling-road-womens-individual-time-trial |title=Rio 2016 |publisher= ;[[File:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre pistol|Men's 50 m pistol]]: [[Jin Jong-oh]] of South Korea recorded an Olympic record of 193.7 in the final to win the gold, coming back from 7th place during the final to become the first shooter to win three consecutive Olympic gold medals in one event. [[Hoàng Xuân Vinh]] (Vietnam) won the silver with 191.3, and [[Kim Song-guk (sport shooter)|Kim Song-guk]] (North Korea) finished at 172.8 to win the bronze.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/36686885|title=Rio Olympics 2016: South Korea's Jin Jong-oh wins third 50m pistol title|publisher=BBC Sports|date=10 August 2016|access-date=7 October 2016}} * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's double trap|Men's double trap]]: Independent Olympic athlete [[Fehaid Al-Deehani]], originally from Kuwait, won the gold medal after beating Italy's [[Marco Innocenti]] in the final. [[Steven Scott]] defeated [[Tim Kneale]] (both from Great Britain) to win the bronze.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/37043261|title=Rio Olympics 2016: Fehaid Al-Deehani wins first independent gold|publisher=BBC Sports|date=10 August 2016|access-date=7 October 2016}} ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre freestyle|Men's 100 m freestyle]]: Eighteen-year-old [[Kyle Chalmers]] (Australia) set a Junior world record of 47.58 in the final to win the gold. [[Pieter Timmers]] (Belgium) finished in second at 47.80, and [[Nathan Adrian]] finished with the bronze with 47.85. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metre breaststroke|Men's 200 m breaststroke]]: [[Dmitriy Balandin]] (Kazakhstan) won the gold with a time of 2:07.46 in the final, [[Josh Prenot]] finished at 2:07.53 to win the silver, and [[Anton Chupkov]] (Russia) won the bronze with a time of 2:07.78 * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metre butterfly|Women's 200 m butterfly]]: The gold went to [[Mireia Belmonte]] of Spain, who recorded a time of 2:04.85 in the final. [[Madeline Groves]] of Australia finished second at 2:04.88, and [[Natsumi Hoshi]] of Japan finished third at 2:05.20. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 200 metre freestyle relay|Women's 4 × 200 m freestyle relay]]: In the final, the United States finished at 7:43.03 to win the gold, Australia finished at 7:44.87 to win the silver, and Canada finished in third with a time of 7:45.39. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|Women's kg|Men's 77 kg]]: [[Nijat Rahimov]] (Kazakhstan) set a world record of 214 kg in the Clean & Jerk, and finished with 379 kg overall, to win the gold. [[Lü Xiaojun]] (China) set a world record of 177 in the Snatch and also finished with a total score of 379 kg, but lost the tiebreaker based on body weight and thus was awarded the silver.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/weightlifting-recap-mens-77kg-and-womens-69kg | title=Weightlifting recap: Nijat Rahimov sets world record, steals gold from Lyu Xiaojun | website=nbcolympics.com | accessdate=11 August 2016}} [[Mohamed Ihab|Mohamed Mahmoud]] of Egypt won the bronze with a final score of 361. * [[Weightlifting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 69 kg|Women's 69 kg]]: [[Xiang Yanmei]] (China) finished with the gold with a final score of 261 kg, [[Zhazira Zhapparkul]] (Kazakhstan) finished at 259 kg to win the silver, and [[Sara Ahmed (weightlifter)|Sara Ahmed]] (Egypt) won the bronze with a final score of 255 kg. {{div col end}} {{collapse bottom}} ===Summary table (day 5)=== {{Collapse top|10 August 2016 — summary table|bg=gold}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Sport ! rowspan="2" | Event ! colspan="3" | Gold medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Silver medalist(s) ! colspan="2" | Bronze medalist(s) ! rowspan="2" | {{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} |- | [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Canoeing]] | [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's slalom K-1|Men's slalom K-1]] | [[Joe Clarke (canoeist)|Joe Clarke]] | {{flagIOC|GBR|2016 Summer}} | | [[Peter Kauzer]] | {{flagIOC|SLO|2016 Summer}} | [[Jiří Prskavec (canoeist, born 1993)|Jiří Prskavec]] | {{flagIOC|CZE|2016 Summer}} |{{cite web|url=https://www.rio2016.com/en/canoe-slalom-kayak-k1-men-final |title=Kayak (K1) Men's Schedule and Results - pair]]: In the final race, [[Eric Murray (rower)|Eric Murray]] and [[Hamish Bond]] (New Zealand) finished with a tome of 6:59.71 to win the gold, [[Lawrence Brittain]] and [[Shaun Keeling]] (South Africa) finished at 7:02.51 to win the silver, and [[Giovanni Abagnale]] and [[Marco Di Costanzo]] (Italy) won the bronze with a time of 7:04.52. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's double sculls|Men's double sculls]]: [[Martin Sinković]] and [[Valent Sinković]] (Croatia) finished the final race with a time of 6:50.28 to win the gold, the silver was won by [[Mindaugas Griškonis]] and [[Saulius Ritter]] (Lithuania) with a time of 6:51.39, and third place went to [[Kjetil Borch]] and [[Olaf Tufte]] (Norway) with a time of 6:53.25. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's quadruple sculls|Men's quadruple sculls]]: Germany won the final race with a time of 6:06.81, Australia finished with the silver at 6:07.96, and the bronze went to Estonia for their time of 6:10.65. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's lightweight coxless four|Men's lightweight coxless four]]: Switzerland finished first in the final race at 6:20.51, Denmark's time of 6:21.97 earned them the silver, and third place went to France and their time of 6:07.32. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's double sculls|Women's double sculls]]: [[Magdalena Fularczyk|Magdalena Fularczyk-Kozłowska]] and [[Natalia Madaj]] (Poland) won the final race with a time of 7:40.10, the silver went to [[Victoria Thornley]] and [[Katherine Grainger]] (Great Britain) and their time of 7:41.05, and Lithuania's [[Donata Vištartaitė]] and [[Milda Valčiukaitė]] finished in third at 7:43.76. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's quadruple sculls|Women's quadruple sculls]]: Germany won the gold after finishing the final race at 6:49:39. The Netherlands won the silver with a time of 6:50:33, and Poland finished at 6:50:86 to win the bronze. ;[[File:Rugby union pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Rugby sevens at the 2016 Summer positions]]: In the final round, [[Barbara Engleder]] (Germany) won the gold with a total score of 458.6, [[Zhang Binbin]] (China) finished in second with 458.4, and [[Du Li]] (China) won the bronze with 447.4. ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metre backstroke|Men's 200 m backstroke]]: [[Ryan Murphy (swimmer)|Ryan Murphy]] (USA) finished the final race with a time of 1:53.62 to win the gold, beating [[Mitch Larkin]] (Australia) and [[Evgeny Rylov]] (Russia), who were slightly behind at 1:53.96 and 1:53.97 to win the silver and bronze, respectively. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metre individual medley|Men's 200 m individual medley]]: In the final, [[Michael Phelps]] (USA) won the gold with a time of 1:54.66, becoming the third athlete and the first swimmer to have won four consecutive Olympic gold medals in one event. [[Kosuke Hagino]] (Japan) won the silver with a time of 1:56.61, and [[Wang Shun]] (China) finished in third with 1:57.05. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metre freestyle|Women's 100 m freestyle]]: In the final, [[Simone Manuel]] (USA) and [[Penny Oleksiak]] (Canada) tied for first place with an Olympic record of 52.70, and thus each were awarded gold medals. Because of the first place tie, no silver medal was awarded, but [[Sarah Sjöström]] (Sweden) was given the bronze after finishing behind them with a time of 52.99. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metre breaststroke|Women's 200 metre breaststroke]]: [[Rie Kaneto]] (Japan) finished the final race at 2:20.30 to win the gold, [[Yulia Yefimova]] (Russia) finished in second at 2:21.97, and [[Shi Jinglin]] (China) finished in third at 2:22.28. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table tennis at Bird-Smith]] finished with 1:19:37 to win the bronze. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 10,000 metres|Women's 10,000 m]]: [[Almaz Ayana]] (Ethiopia) set a world record of 29:17.45 to win the gold, [[Vivian Cheruiyot]] (Kenya) finished with a time of 29:32.53 to win the silver, and [[Tirunesh Dibaba]] (Ethiopia) finished in third at 29:42.56. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's shot put|Women's shot put]]: In the final round, [[Michelle Carter (athlete)|Michelle Carter]] (USA) recorded the farthest distance at 20.63 m to win the gold, [[Valerie Adams]] (New Zealand) won the silver with a distance of 20.42 m, and [[Anita Márton]] (Hungary) throw of 19.87 m earned her the bronze. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the
