and [[Are Strandli]] (Norway) finished in third with 6:31.39. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's coxless four|Men's coxless four]]: The final race saw Great Britain take the gold with a time of 5:58.61. Austria finished in second at 6:00.44, and Italy in third with 6:03.85. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's coxless pair|Women's coxless pair]]: Great Britain's [[Helen Glover (rower)|Helen Glover]] and [[Heather Stanning]] captured the gold with a time of 7:18.29 in the final. New Zealand's [[Genevieve Behrent]] and [[Rebecca Scown]] came in second at 7:19.53, and Denmark's [[Hedvig Rasmussen]] and [[Anne Dsane Andersen|Anne Andersen]] came in third with 7:20.71. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's lightweight double sculls|Women's lightweight double sculls]]: [[Maaike Head]] and [[Ilse Paulis]] of the Netherlands captured the gold with a time of 7:04.73. Finishing at 7:05.88, Canada's [[Lindsay Jennerich]] and [[Patricia Obee]] were awarded the silver, and China's [[Huang Wenyi]] and [[Pan Feihong]] came in third at 7:06.49. ;[[File:Sailing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Sailing]] * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – 49er|49er]]: Races 1 to 3 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – 49erFX|49erFX]]: Races 1 to 3 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 470|Men's 470]]: Races 5 and 6 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 470|Women's 470]]: Races 5 and 6 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's RS:X|Men's RS:X]]: Races 10 to 12 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's RS:X|Women's RS:X]]: Races 10 to 12 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser|Laser]]: Races 7 and 8 * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser Radial|Laser Radial]]: Races 7 and 8 ;[[File:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre rifle prone|Men's 50 m rifle prone]]: The gold went to [[Henri Junghänel]] (Germany), who finished with a total of 209.5.[[Kim Jong-hyun (sport shooter)|Kim Jong-hyun]] (South Korea) finished in second with 208.2, and [[Kirill Grigoryan]] (Russia) finished with 187.3 to earn the bronze. * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's skeet|Women's skeet]]: [[Diana Bacosi]] (Italy) defeated [[Chiara Cainero]] (Italy) in the Gold Medal Match, while [[Kim Rhode]] defeated [[Wei Meng]] in the Bronze Medal Match. ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre freestyle|Men's 50 m freestyle]]: The gold went to [[Anthony Ervin]] (USA) with a time of 21.40 in the final, [[Florent Manaudou]] (France) finished at 21.41 to win the silver, and [[Nathan Adrian]] (USA) finished at 21.49 to win the bronze. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metre butterfly|Men's 100 m butterfly]]: [[Joseph Schooling]] (Singapore) set an Olympic record of 50.39 to win the gold. A three-way tie then occurred at 51.14 for second place, and all three were awarded silver medals: [[Michael Phelps]] (USA), [[Chad le Clos]] (South Africa), and [[László Cseh]] (Hungary). No bronze medals were awarded because of the tie. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 800 metre freestyle|Women's 800 m freestyle]]: [[Katie Ledecky]] (USA) set a world record of 8:04.79 to win the gold, [[Jazmin Carlin]] (Great Britain) finished in second with 8:16.17, and [[Boglárka Kapás]] (Hungary) finished in third with 8:16.37. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 200 metre backstroke|Women's 200 m backstroke]]: The gold went to [[Maya DiRado]] (USA) with a time of 2:05:99, [[Katinka Hosszú]] (Hungary) finished in second with 2:06:05, and [[Hilary Caldwell]] (Canada) finished in third with 2:07:54. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's team|Men's team]]: First Round * [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's team|Women's team]]: First Round ;[[File:Tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Tennis at the Standings |work=rio2016.com |accessdate=12 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826101542/https://www.rio2016.com/en/weightlifting-standings-wl-womens-75kg-2 |archivedate=26 August 2016 |df= }} |} {{Collapse bottom}} ==Day 8 — Saturday 13 August== ===Detailed results (day 8)=== {{Collapse top|13 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Athletics pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 10,000 metres|Men's 10,000 m]]: [[Mo Farah]] (Great Britain) finished with a time of 27:05.17 to win the gold, [[Paul Tanui]] (Kenya) finished in second at 27:05.64, and [[Tamirat Tola]] (Ethiopia) finished in third with 27:06.26. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's long jump|Men's long jump]]: [[Jeff Henderson (athlete)|Jeff Henderson]] of the United States recorded a distance of 8.38 m to win the gold, beating South Africa's [[Luvo Manyonga]]'s distance of 8.37 m. [[Greg Rutherford]] of Great Britain finished in third with 8.29 m. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's discus throw|Men's discus throw]]: [[Christoph Harting]] of Germany recorded a distance of 68.37 m to win the gold. Poland's [[Piotr Małachowski]] won the silver with 67.55 m, and [[Daniel Jasinski]] of Germany finished in third with a distance of 67.05 m. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 100 metres|Women's 100 m]]: In the final race, [[Elaine Thompson]] (Jamaica) won the gold with a time of 10.71. [[Tori Bowie]] (United States) finished in second at 10.83, and [[Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce]] (Jamaica) finished in third with 10.86. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's heptathlon|Women's heptathlon]]: [[Nafissatou Thiam]] (Belgium) won the gold with a total score of 6810, [[Jessica Ennis-Hill]] (Great Britain) finished in second with a total score of 6775, and [[Brianne Theisen Eaton]] (Canada) finished with a total score of 6653 to win the bronze. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Badminton]] * Third Women's team pursuit|Women's team pursuit]]: In the Gold Medal Race, Great Britain set a world record of 3:14.051 to beat the time of 3:19.727 by the United States. Men's single sculls|Men's single sculls]]: In the final, [[Mahé Drysdale]] (New Zealand) won the gold with a time of 6:41.34, [[Damir Martin]] (Croatia) was second at 6:41.34, and [[Ondřej Synek]] (Czech Republic) was third with 6:44.10. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's eight|Men's eight]]: Great Britain finished the final with a time of 5:29.63 to win the gold, Germany finished at 5:30.96 to win the silver, and the Netherlands recorded a time of 5:31.59 to win the bronze. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's single sculls|Women's single sculls]]: [[Kim Brennan]] (Australia) recorded a time of 7:21.54 in the final to capture the gold, [[Genevra Stone]] (United States) came in second at 7:22.92, and [[Duan Jingli]] (China) finished in third with 7:24.13. * [[Rowing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's eight|Women's eight]]: In the final race, the United States won the gold with a time of 6:01.49, Great Britain was second at 6:03.98, and Romania in third with 6:04.10. ;[[File:Sailing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Sailing]] * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – 49er|49er]]: Races 3 to 6 * [[Sailing at [[Christian Reitz]] (Germany) won the gold with 34 in the final, [[Jean Quiquampoix]] (France) came in second with 30, and [[Li Yuehong]] (China) came in third with 27. * [[Shooting at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's skeet|Men's skeet]]: In the Gold Medal Match, [[Gabriele Rossetti (sport shooter)|Gabriele Rossetti]] (Italy) recorded a score of 16, beating the score of 15 set by [[Marcus Svensson]] (Sweden). [[Abdullah Al-Rashidi]], competing as an "[[Independent Olympic Athletes at the 2016 Summer Olympics|independent Olympic athlete]]", scored 16 in the Bronze Medal Match versus the score of 14 recorded by [[Mikola Milchev]] (Ukraine). ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 1500 metre freestyle|Men's 1500 m freestyle]]: In the final, [[Gregorio Paltrinieri]] (Italy) finished at 14:34.57 to win the gold, [[Connor Jaeger]] (United States) finished in second with 14:39.48, and [[Gabriele Detti]] was third at 14:40.86. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metre medley relay|Men's 4 × 100 m medley relay]]: In the final, [[Ryan Murphy (swimmer)|Ryan Murphy]] set a world record time of 51.85 to help the United States team set an overall Olympic record of 3:27.95 to win the gold. Great Britain finished in second with 3:29.24, and Australia was third with 3:29.93. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 50 metre freestyle|Women's 50 m freestyle]]: Pernille Blume (Denmark) finished first in the finals with a time of 24.07, the silver went to [[Simone Manuel]] (United States) after recording a time of 24.09, and [[Aliaksandra Herasimenia]] (Belarus) was third with 24.11. * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 100 metre medley relay|Women's 4 × 100 m medley relay]]: The United States won the gold with a time of 3:53.13 in the final, Australia came in second with 3:55.00, and Denmark was third with 3:55.01. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Table tennis]] * [[Table [[Eunice Kirwa]] (Bahrain) was the silver medalist with a time of 2:24:13, and [[Mare Dibaba]] (Ethiopia) finished in third with a time of 2:24:30. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's triple jump|Women's triple jump]]: [[Caterine Ibargüen]] (Colombia) won the gold with a distance of 15.17 m, [[Yulimar Rojas]] (Venezuela) came in second with a distance of 14.98 m, and [[Olga Standings |work=rio2016.com |accessdate=13 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922175521/https://www.rio2016.com/en/wrestling-standings-wr-mens-greco-roman-75-kg |archivedate=22 September 2016 |df= }} |- | [[Saeid Abdevali]] | {{flagIOC|IRI|2016 Summer}} |} {{Collapse bottom}} ==Day 10 — Monday 15 August== ===Detailed results (day 10)=== {{Collapse top|15 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Athletics pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 800 metres|Men's 800 m]]: In the final, Kenya's [[David Rudisha]] won the gold with a time of 1:42.15, beating Algeria's [[Taoufik Makhloufi]]'s time of 1:42.61, and the United States's [[Clayton Murphy]]'s time of 1:42.93. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's pole vault|Men's pole vault]]: [[Thiago Braz da Silva]] (Brazil) set an olympic record of 6.03 m to win the gold, [[Renaud Lavillenie]] (France) came in second with 5.98 m, and [[Sam Kendricks]] (USA) came in third with 5.85 m. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metres|Women's 400 m]]: [[Shaunae Miller]] (Bahamas) finished with a time of 49:44 in the final to win the gold, diving{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/36689787 | title=Rio Olympics 2016: Shaunae Miller wins 400m gold in thrilling finish | website=bbc.com | date=16 August 2016 | accessdate=16 August 2016}} across the finish line to beat [[Allyson Felix]] (USA), who finished at 49.51. [[Shericka Jackson]] (Jamaica) was third with a time of 49.85. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 3000 metres steeplechase|Women's 3000 m steeplechase]]: [[Ruth Jebet]] (Bahrain) finished first in the final with a time of 8:59.75, [[Hyvin Kiyeng Jepkemoi]] (Kenya) was second at 9:07.12, and [[Emma Coburn]] (USA) was third at 9:07.63. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's hammer throw|Women's hammer throw]]: [[Anita Włodarczyk]] (Poland) set a world record throw of 82.29 m to win the gold. [[Zhang Wenxiu]] (China) won the silver with a throw of 76.75 m, and [[Sophie Hitchon]] (Great Britain) recorded 74.54 m to win the bronze. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] Germany's [[Isabell Werth]] won the silver with a final score of 89.071, and [[Kristina Bröring-Sprehe]] won the bronze with a final score of 87.142. ;[[File:Field hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Field hockey]] * [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: Quarterfinals ** '''{{fhw-rt|NZL}} 4'''–2 {{fhw|AUS}} ** {{fhw-rt|USA}} 1–'''2 {{fhw|GER}}''' ** '''{{fhw-rt|GBR}} 3'''–1 {{fhw|ESP}} ** '''{{fhw-rt|NED}} 3'''–2 {{fhw|ARG}} ;[[File:Gymnastics_(artistic)_pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Gymnastics (artistic)]] * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's vault|Men's vault]]: [[Ri Se-gwang]] (North Korea) finished with a score of 15.691 in the final to win the gold. [[Denis Ablyazin]] (Russia) finished in second with 15.516, and [[Kenzō Shirai]] (Japan) finished in third with 15.449. * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's rings|Men's rings]]: In the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 110 metres hurdles|Men's 110 m hurdles]]: In the final, [[Omar McLeod]] (Jamaica) finished with a time of 13.05 to win the gold, [[Orlando Ortega]] (Spain) was second at 13.17, and [[Dimitri Bascou]] (France) was the bronze medalist at 13.24. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's triple jump|Men's triple jump]]: [[Christian Taylor (athlete)|Christian Taylor]] (USA) won the gold with a distance of 17.86 m, [[Will Claye]] (USA) recorded a distance of 17.76 m to win the silver, and [[Dong Bin]] was third with 17.58. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's high jump|Men's high jump]]: [[Derek Drouin]] (Canada) recorded 2.38 m to win the gold. Silver went to [[Mutaz Essa Barshim]] (Qatar) with 2.36 m, and bronze went to [[Bohdan Bondarenko]] (Ukraine) with 2.33 m. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 1500 metres|Women's 1500 m]]: Kenya's [[Faith Chepngetich Kipyegon]] finished the final with a time of 4:08.92 to win the gold, Ethiopia's [[Genzebe Dibaba]] was second at 4:10.27, and third place went to |[[Jennifer Simpson]] (USA) with a time of 4:10.53. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's discus throw|Women's discus throw]]: [[Sandra Perković]] (Croatia) recorded a distance of 69.21 m to win the gold. A 66.73-m throw by [[Mélina Robert-Michon]] (France) earned her the silver, and [[Denia Caballero]] (Cuba) won the bronze with a 65.34-m throw. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Badminton]] * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles|Men's doubles]]: Semifinals ** [[Chai Biao|Chai]] – [[Hong Wei|Hong]] {{flagicon|CHN}} 1–'''2 {{flagicon|MAS}} [[Goh V Shem|Goh]] – [[Tan Wee Kiong|Tan]]''' ** '''[[Fu Haifeng|Fu]] – [[Zhang Nan (badminton)|Zhang]] {{flagicon|CHN}} 2'''–0 {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Marcus Ellis|Ellis]] – [[Chris Langridge|Langridge]] * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|Women's singles]]: Quarterfinals ** '''[[Carolina Marín]] {{flagicon|ESP}} 2'''–0 {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Sung Ji-hyun]] ** '''[[Li Xuerui]] {{flagicon|CHN}} 2'''–0 {{flagicon|THA}} [[Porntip Buranaprasertsuk]] ** '''[[Nozomi Okuhara]] {{flagicon|JPN}} 2'''–1 {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Akane Yamaguchi]] ** '''[[P. metres|Men's C-1 1000 m]]: [[Sebastian Brendel]] (Germany) won the final race with a time of 3:56.926. [[Isaquias Queiroz]] (Brazil) finished in second with a time of 3:58.529. [[Serghei Tarnovschi]] (Moldova) was initially awarded the bronze with a time of 4:00.852, but was later stripped of the medal for a doping violation. [[Ilia Shtokalov]] (Russia) was then given the bronze with a time of 4:00.963.{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/int-canoe-federation-canoe-bronze-medalist-serghei-tarnovschi-173734307--spt.html|title=Serghei Tarnovschi of Moldova has been suspended|website=sports.yahoo.com|accessdate=21 August 2016}} * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's K-1 1000 metres|Men's K-1 1000 m]]: In the final, Spain's [[Marcus Walz]] finished first with a time of 3:31.447. Second place was [[Josef Dostál (canoeist)|Josef Dostál]] of the Czech Republic with a time of 3:32.145. Russia's [[Roman Anoshkin]] finished third at 3:33.363. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's K-1 200 metres|Women's K-1 200 m]]: [[Lisa Carrington]] (New Zealand) won the final race with a time of 39.864, [[Marta Walczykiewicz]] (Poland) was second at 40.279, and [[Inna Osypenko-Radomska]] (Azerbaijan) finished third at 40.401. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's K-2 500 metres|Women's K-2 500 m]]: The gold went to Hungary's [[Gabriella Szabó]] and [[Danuta Kozák]], who finished the final race with a time of 1:43.687, behind the time of 1:43.738 set by Germany's [[Franziska Weber]] and [[Tina Dietze]]. With a time of 1:45.207, Poland's [[Karolina Naja]] and [[Beata Mikołajczyk]] were awarded the bronze. ;[[File:Cycling (track) pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Cycling (track)]] * [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's Keirin|Men's Keirin]]: In the final race, [[Jason Kenny]] (Great Britain) finished at 10.113 to win the gold, [[Matthijs Buchli]] (Netherlands) was +0.040 back to win the silver, and [[Azizulhasni Awang]] (Malaysia) was +0.085 back to win the bronze. * [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's Omnium|Women's Omnium]]: [[Laura Kenny|Laura Trott]] (Great Britain) won the gold with a final score of 230, [[Sarah Hammer]] (USA) finished in second with 206 points, and [[Jolien D'Hoore]] (Belgium) was third with 199 points. * [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's sprint|Women's sprint]]: [[Kristina Vogel]] (Germany) beat [[Becky James]] (Great Britain) in the Gold Medal Race. In the bronze Medal Race, [[Katy Marchant]] (Great Britain) beat [[Elis Ligtlee]] (Netherlands). ;[[File:Diving pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Diving]] * [[Diving parallel bars]]: [[Oleg Verniaiev]] (Ukraine) was awarded a final score of 16.041 and the gold, [[Danell Leyva]] was awarded a final score of 15.900 and the silver, and [[David Belyavskiy]] (Russia) was awarded a final score of 15.783 and the bronze. * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's horizontal bar|Men's horizontal bar]]: [[Fabian Hambüchen]] (Germany) won the gold after being given a final score of 15.766, [[Danell Leyva]] (USA) was the silver medalist after being given a final score of 15.500, and [[Nile Wilson]] (Great Britain) finished in third after being awarded a final score of 15.466. * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's floor|Women's floor]]: [[Simone Biles]] (USA) won the gold, based on being awarded a total score of 15.966. [[Aly Raisman]] (USA) was given a total score of 15.500 to win the silver. [[Amy Tinkler]] (Great Britain) was judged to have a total score of 14.933 to win the bronze. ;[[File:Handball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Handball]] * [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: Quarterfinals ** {{hbw-rt|BRA}} 23–'''32 {{hbw|NED}}''' ** {{hbw-rt|ESP}} 26–'''27 {{tooltip|(OT)|Overtime}} {{hbw|FRA}}''' ** {{hbw-rt|SWE}} 20–'''33 {{hbw|NOR}} ** '''{{hbw-rt|RUS}} 31'''–27 {{hbw|ANG}} ;[[File:Sailing pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Sailing]] * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Finn|Finn]]: [[Giles Scott]] (Great Britain) won the gold, finishing with the lowest total score of 36.0, [[Vasilij Žbogar]] (Slovenia) finished with the second lowest score of 68.0, and [[Caleb Paine]] (USA) won the bronze with a total score of 76.0. * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser|Laser]]: With a total score of 73.0 [[Tom Burton (sailor)|Tom Burton]] (Australia) won the gold. Silver went to [[Tonči Stipanović]] (Croatia) with a score of 75.0, and [[Sam Meech]] (New Zealand) won the bronze, having the third lowest final score of 85.0. * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Laser Radial|Laser Radial]]: [[Marit Bouwmeester]] (Netherlands) was awarded the gold with a total of 61.0, [[Annalise Murphy]] (Ireland) won the silver with 67.0, and [[Anne-Marie Rindom]] (Denmark) won the bronze with 71.0. * [[Sailing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Nacra 17|Nacra 17]]: [[Santiago Lange]] and [[Cecilia Carranza Saroli]] of Argentina finished with 77 points to win the gold, one overall position behind [[Jason Waterhouse]] and [[Lisa Darmanin]] of Australia, and [[Thomas Zajac]] and [[Tanja Frank]] of Austria ;[[File:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] * [[Swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon 10 kilometre|Men's marathon 10 km]]: [[Ferry Weertman]] (Netherlands) won the gold medal with a time of 1:52:59.8, [[Spyridon Gianniotis]] (Greece) finished close behind to win the silver, and [[Marc-Antoine Olivier]] (France) was 2.22 seconds behind to win the bronze. ;[[File:Synchronized swimming pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Synchronized swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Synchronized swimming]] * [[Synchronized swimming at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's duet|Duet]]: The gold was awarded to Russia's [[Natalia Ishchenko]] and [[Svetlana Romashina]] after being given a final score of 194.9910. China's [[Huang Xuechen]] and [[Sun Wenyan]] was awarded a second place final score of 192.3688. In third place, a final score of 188.0547 was awarded to Japan's team of [[Yukiko Inui]] and [[Risako Mitsui]]. ;[[File:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Table tennis at the 2016 Summer [[Brittney Reese]] (USA) won the silver with a distance of 7.15 m, and [[Ivana Španović]] was third with 7.08 m. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer The American appeal was upheld, as it was judged to be caused by [[Franciela Krasucki]] of the Brazilian team bumping [[Allyson Felix]] as she approached the handoff to [[English Gardner]]. Team USA was then given a second chance to qualify for the final, running by themselves later in the day.{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/sports/Track-and-Field-Decathlon-Rio-Olympics-Day-13-390553331.html |title=US Relay Women Get Extra Shot after bungled race |work=NBC |date=18 August 2016}} The new qualifying time resulted in displacing China from the final. * Jamaica's [[Usain Bolt]] won the gold in the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metres|men's 200 m]] for the third successive Summer Olympics, recording a time of 19.78 in the final. [[Andre De Grasse]] (Canada) finished in second at 20.02, and [[Christophe Lemaitre]] (France) finished in third at 20.12. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres hurdles|Men's 400 m hurdles]]: [[Kerron Clement]] (USA) finished first in the final with a time of 47.73, beating the 47.78 time of [[Boniface Mucheru Tumuti]] (Kenya). [[Yasmani Copello]] (Turkey) was third with a time of 47.92. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's shot put|Men's shot put]]: [[Ryan Crouser]] (USA) recorded an Olympic record of 22.52 m to win the gold. [[Joe Kovacs]] (USA) was second with a throw of 21.78, and [[Tomas Walsh]] (New Zealand) was third with a throw of 21.36. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's decathlon|Men's decathlon]]: [[Ashton Eaton]] (USA) won the gold with a final score of 8893, [[Kévin Mayer]] (France) won the silver with 8834 points, and [[Damian Warner]] (Canada) finished third with 8666 points. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 400 metres hurdles|Women's 400 m hurdles]]: [[Dalilah Muhammad]] of the United States finished first in the final with a time of 53.13, beating [[Sara Petersen (hurdler)|Sara Petersen]] of Denmark (52.55) and [[Ashley Spencer (athlete)|Ashley Spencer]] of the United States (53.72). * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's javelin throw|Women's javelin throw]]: [[Sara Kolak]] (Croatia) recorded a throw of 66.18 m to win the gold, [[Sunette Viljoen]] (South Africa) was second with a distance of 64.92 m, and [[Barbora Špotáková]] (Czech Republic) was third with 64.80 m. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Badminton]] * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles|Men's doubles]]: Bronze Medal Game ** [[Chai Biao|Chai]] – [[Hong Wei|Hong]] {{flagicon|CHN}} 1–'''2 {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Marcus Ellis|Ellis]] – [[Chris Langridge|Langridge]] {{bronze3}}''' * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|Women's singles]]: Semifinals ** '''[[Carolina Marín]] {{flagicon|ESP}} 2'''–0 {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Li Xuerui]] ** [[Nozomi Okuhara]] {{flagicon|JPN}} 0–'''2 {{flagicon|IND}} [[P. [[Valentin Demyanenko]] (Azerbaijan) came in second at 39.493, and [[Isaquias Queiroz]] (Brazil) came in third with 39.628. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's K-2 200 metres|Men's K-2 200 m]]: [[Saúl Craviotto]] and [[Cristian Toro]] (Spain) finished first in the final with a time of 32.075. [[Liam Heath]] and [[Jon Schofield (canoeist)|Jon Schofield]] (Great Britain) won the silver with a time of 32.368, and [[Aurimas Lankas]] and [[Edvinas Ramanauskas]] (Lithuania) finished third at 32.382. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's K-2 1000 metres|Men's K-2 1000 m]]: The final and the gold medal was won by [[Max Rendschmidt]] and [[Marcus Gross]] (Germany) with a time of 3:10.781, the silver went to [[Marko Tomićević]] and [[Milenko Zorić]] (Serbia) with a time of 3:10.969, and third place was won by [[Ken Wallace (canoeist)|Ken Wallace]] and [[Lachlan Tame]] (Australia) with a time of 3:12.593. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's K-1 500 metres|Women's K-1 500 m]]: Hungary's [[Danuta Kozák]] finished first in the final with a time of Standings |work=rio2016.com |accessdate=18 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922183911/https://www.rio2016.com/en/wrestling-standings-wr-womens-freestyle-75-kg |archivedate=22 September 2016 |df= }} |- |[[Ekaterina Bukina]] |{{flagIOC|RUS|2016 Summer}} |} {{collapse bottom}} ==Day 14 — Friday 19 August== ===Detailed results (day 14)=== {{Collapse top|19 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Athletics pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] * With a time of 37.27 in the final, Jamaica won the gold in the [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metres relay|men's 4 × 100 m relay]] for the third consecutive Olympics. Japan won the silver with a time of 37.60, and Canada captured the bronze with a time of 37.64. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 kilometres walk|Men's 50 km walk]]: [[Matej Tóth]] (Slovakia) finished with a time of 3:40:58 to win the gold and [[Jared Tallent]] (Australia) finished at 3:41:16 to win the bronze. [[Hirooki Arai]] (Japan) initially was awarded the bronze with a time of 3:41:24 and [[Evan Dunfee]] (Canada) came in fourth at 3:41:24. Canada filed a protest based on the contact with Arai, resulting in Arai's disqualification. Japan then filed a counter-protest, which reversed the decision and gave the bronze back to Arai.{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/sports/rio-2016/canadas-evan-dunfee-wins-race-walking-bronze-after-japanese-walker-disqualified-for-last-lap-bump |title=Canada’s Evan Dunfee loses race-walking bronze medal after Japan protests Canadian protest |work=National Post |date=19 August 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2016}} * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's hammer throw|Men's hammer throw]]: Tajikistan's [[Dilshod Nazarov]] recorded a throw of 78.68 m to win the gold, [[Ivan Tsikhan]] of Belarus won the silver with a throw 77.79 m, and [[Wojciech Nowicki]] of Poland cam in third with a distance of 77.73 m. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 5000 metres|Women's 5000 m]]: [[Vivian Cheruiyot]] of Kenya finished first in the final with an Olympic record time of 14:26.17, beating Kenya's [[Hellen Onsando Obiri]] (14:29.77) and Ethiopia's [[Almaz Ayana]] (14:33.59). * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 100 metres relay|Women's 4 × 100 m relay]]: The United States won the gold by finishing the final with a time of 41.01, Jamaica came in second at 41.36, and Great Britain came in third at 41.77. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 20 kilometres walk|Women's 20 km walk]]: [[Liu Hong (racewalker)|Liu Hong]] (China) finished first with a time of 1:28:35 to win the gold, beating Mexico's [[María Guadalupe González]] (1:28:37) and China's [[Lü Xiuzhi]] (1:28:42). * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's pole vault|Women's pole vault]]: [[Ekaterini Stefanidi]] (Greece) won the gold with a vault of 4.85 m, beating [[Sandi Morris]] (USA) on the tiebreaker based on the number of misses. [[Eliza McCartney]] (New Zealand) won the bronze with a vault of 4.80 m, beating [[Alana Boyd]] (Australia) on the tiebreaker based on the number of misses. ;[[File:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Badminton]] * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|Men's singles]]: Semifinals ** '''[[Lee Chong Wei]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 2'''–1 {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Lin Dan]] ** [[Viktor Axelsen]] {{flagicon|DEN}} 0–'''2 {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Chen Long]]''' * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles|Men's doubles]]: Gold Medal Game ** {{silver2}} [[Goh V Shem|Goh]] – [[Tan Wee Kiong|Tan]] {{flagicon|MAS}} 1–'''2 {{flagicon|CHN}} [[Fu Haifeng|Fu]] – [[Zhang Nan (badminton)|Zhang]] {{gold1}}''' * [[Badminton at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's singles|Women's singles]]: ** Bronze Medal Game: [[Li Xuerui]] {{flagicon|CHN}} – '''({{tooltip|w/o|Walkover}}){{flagicon|JPN}} [[Nozomi Okuhara]] {{bronze3}}''' ** Gold Medal Game: '''{{gold1}} [[Carolina Marín]] {{flagicon|ESP}} 2'''–1 {{flagicon|IND}} [[P. [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's BMX|Men's BMX]]: In the final, [[Connor Fields]] (USA) won the gold with a time of 34.642, [[Jelle van Gorkom]] (Netherlands) finished in second at 35.316, and [[Carlos Ramirez (BMX rider)|Carlos Ramirez]] (Colombia) won the bronze with 35.517. * [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's BMX|Women's BMX]]: [[Mariana Pajón]] (Colombia) won the final with a time of 34.093 to win the gold, beating the time of 34.435 set by [[Alise Post]] (USA) and the time of 34.755 set by third-place finisher [[Stefany Hernandez]] (Venezuela) ;[[File:Diving pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Diving]] * [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 10 metre platform|Men's 10 m platform]]: Preliminaries ;[[File:Equestrian pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Equestrian]] * A six-way tie for first place in the final of the [[Equestrian at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Individual jumping|individual jumping competition]] required a Gold medal jump-off. [[Nick Skelton]] (Great Britain) then won the gold with a time of 42.82, and [[Peder Fredricson]] (Sweden) won the silver with a time of 43.35. [[Eric Lamaze]] (Canada) finished with a time of 42.09 in the jump-off, but four penalties dropped him to the bronze. ;[[File:Field hockey pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Field hockey]] * [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: ** Bronze Medal Game: '''{{bronze3}} {{fhw-rt|GER}} 2'''–1 {{fhw|NZL}} ** Gold Medal Game: {{silver2}} {{fhw-rt|NED}} 3 (0)–'''3 (2) ({{tooltip|p.s.o.|Penalty shoot-out}}) {{fhw|GBR}} {{gold1}} ;[[File:Football pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football]] * [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|Women's tournament]]: ** Bronze Medal Game: {{fbw-rt|BRA}} 1–'''2 {{fbw|CAN}} {{bronze3}}''' ** Gold Medal Game: {{silver2}} {{fbw-rt|SWE}} 1–'''2 {{fbw|GER}} {{gold1}}''' ;[[File:Golf pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Golf]] * [[Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's individual|Women's individual]]: Round 3 ;[[File:Gymnastics_(rhythmic)_pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Gymnastics (rhythmic)]] * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's rhythmic individual all-around|Women's rhythmic individual all-around]]: Qualification round ;[[File:Handball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Handball]] * [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]]: Semifinals ** {{hb-rt|POL}} 28–'''29 ({{tooltip|ET|Overtime}}) {{hb|DEN}}''' ** '''{{hb-rt|FRA}} 29'''–28 {{hb|GER}} ;[[File:Modern pentathlon pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Modern pentathlon at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Modern pentathlon]] * [[Modern pentathlon at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's|Women's competition]]: [[Chloe Esposito]] (Australia) won the gold, setting an Olympic record with an overall score of 1372 points. Standings |work=rio2016.com |accessdate=18 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922184447/https://www.rio2016.com/en/wrestling-standings-wr-mens-freestyle-125-kg |archivedate=22 September 2016 |df= }} |- | [[Soner Demirtaş]] | {{flagIOC|TUR|2016 Summer}} |} {{collapse bottom}} ==Day 15 — Saturday 20 August== ===Detailed results (day 15)=== {{Collapse top|20 August 2016 — detailed results|bg=lightblue}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} ;[[File:Athletics pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 1500 metres|Men's 1500 m]]: In the final, [[Matthew Centrowitz, Jr.]] (USA) won the gold with a time of 3:50.00, beating [[Taoufik Makhloufi]] (Algeria) by 0.11 and [[Nick Willis]] (New Zealand) by 0.24. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|Men's 5000 m]]: [[Mo Farah]] (Great Britain) finished the final with a time of 13:03.30 to win the gold. [[Hagos Gebrhiwet]] (Ethiopia) finished second at 13:04.35, and [[Bernard Lagat]] (USA) was third at 13:06.78. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 400 metres relay|Men's 4 × 400 m relay]]: The gold was won by the United States, finishing the final with a time of 2:57.30, followed by Jamaica at 2:58.16, and the Bahamas at 2:58.49. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's javelin throw|Men's javelin throw]]: [[Thomas Röhler]] (Germany) won the gold with a throw of 90.30 m. [[Julius Yego]] (Kenya) recorded a distance of 88.24 m to win the silver, and [[Keshorn Walcott]] (Trinidad and Tobago) had a throw of 85.38 m to win the bronze. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 800 metres|Women's 800 m]]: The final was won by [[Caster Semenya]] (South Africa) with a time of 1:55.28. [[Francine Niyonsaba]] (Burundi) was second at 1:56.49, and [[Margaret Wambui]] (Kenya) was third at 1:56.89. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's 4 × 400 metres relay|Women's 4 × 400 m relay]]: The United States won the gold with a time of 3:19.06 in the final, Jamaica was second at 3:20.34, and Great Britain was third at 3:25.88. * [[Athletics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's high jump|Women's high jump]]: After four competitors tied at clearing the winning of height of 1.97 m (and then all failing to jump the next height of 2.00 m), the medals were decided by the following tiebreakers: [[Ruth Beitia]] (Spain) won the gold based on having no misses prior to the bar being raised to 2.00 m, [[Mirela Demireva]] (Bulgaria) was awarded the silver by having only one miss prior to the 2.00 m height, and [[Blanka Vlašić]] (Croatia) was awarded the bronze over [[Chaunte Lowe]] (USA) based on needing fewer attempts to clear the winning 1.97 m height. Olympics|Canoeing (sprint)]] * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's C-2 1000 metres|Men's C-2 1000 m]]: [[Sebastian Brendel]] and [[Jan Vandrey]] (Germany) won the final with a time of 3:43.912. [[Erlon Silva]] and [[Isaquias Queiroz]] (Brazil) was second at 3:44.819. [[Dmytro Ianchuk]] and [[Taras Mishchuk]] (Ukraine) finished at 3:45.949 to win the bronze. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's K-1 200 metres|Men's K-1 200 m]]: Great Britain's [[Liam Heath]] finished the final at 35.197 to win the gold. [[Maxime Beaumont]] of France won the silver at 35.362. Two bronze medals were then each awarded to Spain's [[Saúl Craviotto]] and Germany's [[Ronald Rauhe]] after they both tied for third at 35.662. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's K-4 1000 metres|Men's K-4 1000 m]]: The final was won at 3:02.143 by Germany, Slovakia finished second at 3:05.044, and the Czech Republic won the bronze with a time of 3:05.176. * [[Canoeing at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's K-4 500 metres|Women's K-4 500 m]]: The gold was awarded to Hungary with a time of 1:34.482 in the final, Germany came in second at 1:35.383, and Belarus was third at 1:36.908. ;[[File:Cycling (mountain biking) pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Cycling (mountain bike)]] * [[Cycling at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's cross-country|Women's cross-country]]: Sweden's Jenny Rissveds crossed the finish line first with a time of 1h 30' 15", beating Poland's [[Maja Włoszczowska]]'s time of 1h 30' 52". Canada's [[Catharine Pendrel]] was third at 1h 31' 41". ;[[File:Diving pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Diving]] * [[Diving at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's 10 metre platform|Men's 10 m platform]]: [[Chen Aisen]] (China) was awarded a final score of 585.30 to win the gold, [[Germán Sánchez (diver)|Germán Sánchez]] (Mexico) finished with a final score of 532.70 to win the silver, and the bronze was awarded to [[David Boudia]] (USA) with a final score of 525.25. ;[[File:Football pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Football]] * [[Football at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's tournament]]: ** Bronze Medal Game: {{fbo-rt|HON}} 2–'''3 {{fbo|NGA}} {{bronze3}} ** Gold Medal Game: '''{{gold1}} {{fbo-rt|BRA}} 1 (5)'''–1 (4) ({{tooltip|pen.|Penalty shoot-out}}) {{fbo|GER}} {{silver2}} ;[[File:Golf pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Golf]] * [[Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's individual|Women's individual]]: [[Inbee Park]] (South Korea) won the gold with a final score of 16 under par, [[Lydia Ko]] (New Zealand) finished 11 under par to win the silver, and [[Shanshan Feng]] (China) won the bronze with a final score of 10 under par. ;[[File:Gymnastics_(rhythmic)_pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Gymnastics (rhythmic)]] * [[Gymnastics at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Women's rhythmic individual all-around|Women's rhythmic individual all-around]]: [[Margarita Mamun]] (Russia) won the gold after being awarded a final score of 76.483. [[Yana Kudryavtseva]] (Russia) was awarded a final total of 75.608 to win the silver. [[Ganna Rizatdinova]] (Ukraine) won the bronze with a final score of 73.583. ;[[File:Handball pictogram.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[Handball at the 2016 Summer Olympics|Handball]] * [[Handball at the 2016 Standings |work=rio2016.com |accessdate=18 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160922184541/https://www.rio2016.com/en/wrestling-standings-wr-mens-freestyle-97-kg |archivedate=22 September 2016 |df=dmy }} |- | [[Magomed Idrisovitch Ibragimov|Magomed Ibragimov]] | {{flagIOC|UZB|2016 Summer}} |} {{collapse bottom}} ==Notes== :''* Athlete who participated in the heats only and received medals.'' :''† Bronze medalist(s) were determined on the previous days.'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|2016 Summer Olympics medal winners}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160710103926/https://www.rio2016.com/en Official website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160806022227/https://www.rio2016.com/en/medal-count-athletes Medal winners] {{Chronological summaries of the Olympics}} {{Events at the 2016 Summer Olympics}} [[Category:2016 Summer Olympics|Chronological summary]] [[Category:Chronological summaries of the Olympics|2016]]

page.title: Consol Energy Mine Map Preservation Project

revision.comment: added [[Category:Energy history of the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = CONSOL Energy Mine Map Preservation Project | logo =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:CONSOLstatus1.jpg|thumb|{{Deletable image-caption|Monday, February 07, 2011|date=February 2011}}]] --> | type = | founded_date = | dissolved = | location = [[University of Pittsburgh]] | key_people = Jeanann Haas Croft, Amy E. Baker, Ashley Cox | area_served = [[Pittsburgh metropolitan area|Southwestern Pennsylvania]] | product = | focus = mine map preservation, digitization and archiving | homepage = [http://www.library.pitt.edu/mine_maps/ homepage] }} The '''CONSOL Energy Mine Map Preservation Project''' is a project to preserve and digitize maps of underground coal mines in Southwestern Pennsylvania.
The project is a joint venture between the [[Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection]], the [[United States Department of the Interior]] [[Office of Surface Mining]], the [[University of Pittsburgh]] University Library System, and [[CONSOL Energy]].<ref name=aeb59>{{cite web|last=Baker |first=Amy E. |title=CONSOL Energy Mine Map Preservation Project |work=www.pitt.edu |publisher= |date=2009-08-26 |url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/index.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w9UKXLTO?url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/index.html |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Origins== The origin of the collection traces back to 1991, when the Pennsylvania-based coal company [[CONSOL Energy]] began depositing mine map materials at the [[University of Pittsburgh]] archives.<ref name=aeb59 /> By 2004, CONSOL Energy had donated a vast collection of records, survey books, photographs, and mining maps.<ref name=partner>{{cite web| title = ULS partners to preserve mining maps| work = University Times| publisher = | date = January 22, 2009| url = http://mac10.umc.pitt.edu/u/FMPro?-DB=ustory&-Format=d.html&-lay=a&storyid=8474&-Find| archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5lcDOFASU?url=http://mac10.umc.pitt.edu/u/FMPro?-DB=ustory&-Format=d.html&-lay=a&storyid=8474&-Find| archivedate = 2009-11-28| deadurl = yes| df = }}</ref> Overall, the collection has grown to over 8,000 individual map sheets relating to mines operated by CONSOL Energy and its corporate subsidiaries throughout Southwestern Pennsylvania in [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny]], [[Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania|Westmoreland]], [[Washington County, Pennsylvania|Washington]], [[Greene County, Pennsylvania|Greene]], [[Fayette County, Pennsylvania|Fayette]], and [[Somerset County, Pennsylvania|Somerset Counties]].<ref name=aeb59 /> The maps are needed for mine safety, transportation planning, mine subsidence insurance.<ref name=aic08 /> The program often consults with homeowners and developers building new properties or dealing with mine subsidence.<ref name=chronicle /> The preservation of historic mine maps took on increased importance following the [[Quecreek Mine Rescue]] in [[Somerset County, Pennsylvania]], where the rescue was hampered by faulty maps.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Smith |first=Craig |title=Project preserves, digitizes maps of thousands of mines |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Tribune Review]] |date=January 16, 2009 |url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/business/s_607371.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w9UL5lSn?url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/business/s_607371.html |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In 2009, the project received $100,000 to be paid over five years from [[CONSOL Energy]], $75,000 from the [[Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection]] and $25,000 from the [[Office of Surface Mining]].<ref name=chronicle />
==Map collections== The collection dates between 1854 and 2002, with most maps dating between 1880 and 1940.<ref name=aeb59 /> The project preservation and digitization efforts are focused on roughly 700 “hardback” maps, which are drafted by hand on heavyweight paper adhered to canvas. The hardback maps are generally oversized, sometimes 5 feet tall and 10 to 30 feet long. These maps, which were used as the "master copies" for other map reproductions, are generally considered the most complete, and sometimes the exclusive map of some abandoned mines.<ref name=aeb59 />
==Conservation & Digitization process== In 2007, University Library System staff members began the process of surveying, cleaning, and repairing the maps in order to stabilize them.<ref name=aeb59 /> Maps are dry cleaned with soot sponges to remove surface dirt. [[File:gastonvilleclean.jpg|thumb|alt= Map cleaned with soot sponges |A mine map that has been cleaned with soot sponges on the left half]]
The canvas backing of the maps are vacuumed; those with significant damage are repaired with muslin patches and an [[Ethylene vinyl acetate]] adhesive.<ref name=treatment>{{cite web|last=Baker |first=Amy E. |title=Treatment: CONSOL Energy Mine Map Preservation Project |work=www.pitt.edu |publisher= |date=2009-02-18 |url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/treatment.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lcDUEJT1?url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/treatment.html |archivedate=2009-11-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In order to unroll brittle maps, some of which haven't been opened in over 100 years, the conservator and student assistants use a process of humidification, flattening, and drying to safely open the maps without causing additional damage.<ref name=treatment /> First, the maps are placed in a large humidity dome. After 5 or 6 hours of absorbing humidity the maps can be safely unrolled.<ref name=treatment /> The maps dry flat between polyester webbing and wool felts overnight.<ref name=treatment /> The majority of student assistants performing the preservation work are enrolled in the [[University of Pittsburgh School of Information Sciences]].<ref name=aic08>{{cite web|last=Croft |first=Jean Ann |author2=Amy Baker |author3=Joseph Taranto |author4=James Welsh |title=What Lies Beneath: Treatment of Canvas-backed Pennsylvania Coal Mining Maps for Digitization |work=www.pitt.edu |publisher=University Library System |year=2008 |url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/aic08.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lcDkxYVP?url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/aic08.pdf |archivedate=2009-11-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Next, the maps are transferred to the [[Office of Surface Mining]] [[National Mine Map Repository]] in [[Green Tree]], [[Pennsylvania]], where they are catalogued and scanned into a digital format.<ref name=aeb59 /> The scanning process uses an overhead Cruse scanner that has a suction table for maps that do not lay flat.<ref name=scanning>{{cite web|last=Baker |first=Amy E. |title=Scanning: CONSOL Energy Mine Map Preservation Project |work=www.pitt.edu |publisher= |date=2009-01-26 |url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/scanning.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lcEGHDiy?url=http://www.pitt.edu/~aeb59/scanning.html |archivedate=2009-11-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The scanned image files are recorded in [[Tagged Image File Format|.tiff]] file format.<ref name=scanning /> The [[Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection]] office in [[California, Pennsylvania]] [[Georeference|prepares]] then the digital files for use in [[geographic information system]] programs for use within the Pennsylvania Historical Underground Mine Maps Inventory System.<ref name=aeb59 /><ref name=chronicle>{{cite web|last=Blake |first=Sharon S. |title=Pitt’s ULS Gets $200,000 to Continue Restoring Century-old CONSOL Mining Maps |work=Pitt Chronicle |publisher= |date=January 20, 2009 |url=http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/?p=2030 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616233759/http://www.chronicle.pitt.edu/?p=2030 |archivedate=2010-06-16 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The original maps are returned to University of Pittsburgh archives for permanent storage.<ref name=aeb59 />
==Use== The information is proving useful to homeowners who live atop old mines, and even to developers of a new regional botanical garden.<ref name=New>{{cite web |last=Kaufmann |first=Leah |title=New Information from Old Mine Maps |year=2009 |url=http://www.alleghenyfront.org/story.html?storyid=200908031141570.970735 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110619051747/http://www.alleghenyfront.org/story.html?storyid=200908031141570.970735 |archivedate=2011-06-19 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[National Mine Map Repository]] * [[Office of Surface Mining]] * [[Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection]] * [[University of Pittsburgh]] * [[CONSOL Energy]]
==References== * {{cite web| last = Croft | first = Jean Ann |author2=Debora Rougeux| title = Assessment and Plans to Preserve the CONSOL Energy Mining Map Collection| work = | publisher = | year = 2006| url = http://www.archival.com/newsletters/apnewsvol13no4.pdf}} * {{cite web| last = Kaufmann | first = Leah | title = New Information from Old Mine Maps | year = 2009 | url = http://www.alleghenyfront.org/story.html?storyid=200908031141570.970735}} * {{cite web| last = Mastroianni | first = Dana | title = A Partnership for Preserving Mining Heritage|work = WPA/WV ACRL Chapter Newsletter| year = 2009 | url = http://3280977528666745727-a-1802744773732722657-s-sites.googlegroups.com/site/wpwvcacrlorg/home/about/chapter-documents-1/NewsletterFall2009.PDF?attachauth=ANoY7cqUfV2QjkXmM8FJ5PWVKFYu7-Qca4bvE5Bn8gKSgQ_Y67e0ZGnZi0gmXTVI6G5KYCJBWJBYwWZPGmOD8_cNpVlPY3vQV9QvYieBo-UthEEnKsJz5zl3iB2EItZjVfwNiMetpp-2vjFgSVdSBMuVbFlfZm_O33UYfrzAGyzTuT_j0EHU0lRp52oB-TTCPhp4ukVPAF-SMKzbsrzz_THIH369y66xvlOXXvrYsY5t6r-Iq4T1xPxDyAXeqLUR6gEaAEMZWzlz&attredirects=0}} *{{cite conference| last = Baker |first = Amy | title = Preservation of Archival Mining Maps: Increasing Access and Safety| booktitle = VuStuff II | place = Villanova, PA | publisher = Villanova University | date = October 12, 2011 |url = http://vustuff.org/vustuff/conferences/}}
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Pennsylvania maps]] [[Category:Web archiving initiatives]] [[Category:University of Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Historical geographic information systems]] [[Category:History of mining in the United States]] [[Category:Geography of Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Archives in the United States]] [[Category:Preservation (library and archival science)]] [[Category:Energy history of the United States]]

revision.comment: clean up spacing around commas, replaced: ,M → , M
revision.text:
The [[writ]] of '''''coram nobis''''' (also known as ''writ of error coram nobis'', ''writ of coram vobis'', or ''writ of error coram vobis'') is a legal order allowing a court to correct its original judgment upon discovery of a [[fundamental error]] that did not appear in the records of the original judgment's proceedings and would have prevented the judgment from being pronounced.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=2020995530047118426&q=coram+nobis&hl=en&as ''State v. Mixon'', 983 S.W.2d 661, 672 (Tenn. 1999)]</ref> The term "coram nobis" is Latin for "before us" and the meaning of its full form, ''quae coram nobis resident'', is "which [things] remain in our presence". The writ of coram nobis originated in the [[England and Wales|English]] court of [[common law]] in the [[English legal system]] during the [[16th century|sixteenth century]].
The writ of coram nobis still exists today in a few courts in the United States. In 1907, the writ became obsolete in England and replaced by other means of correcting errors; however, the writ survives in the United States in various forms in the [[Federal judiciary of the United States|federal courts]], in sixteen [[State court (United States)|state courts]], and the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia|District of Columbia courts]]. For those courts with the authority to issue a writ of coram nobis, the rules and guidelines differ – sometimes significantly. Each state is free to operate its own coram nobis procedures independent of other state courts as well as the federal court system. In other words, the criteria required to issue the writ in one state (or federal) court system are different from the criteria required to issue the writ in a different court system. A writ can be granted only by the court where the original judgment was entered, so those seeking to correct a judgment must understand the criteria required for that specific court.
==History==
===England=== The ''writ of error coram nobis'' originated in England over 500 years ago. The name of the writ combines three terms: writ, writ of error, and coram nobis. '''Writ''' is an official written command. '''Writ of error''' provides a superior court the means to correct errors of a lower court. Writ of error '''''coram nobis''''' is a variation of the writ of error and provides a court the means to correct its own errors.<ref>Robinson, Edward N. [https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1559&context=dlj ''The Writs of Error Coram Nobis and Coram Vobis''.] Duke Bar Journal 2.1 (1951): 29-39. p.30.</ref>
[[Image:Edward the Confessor sealed writ.jpg|thumb|A sealed writ of [[Edward the Confessor]], a king of England who died in 1066 – the same year as the Norman Conquest]]
==== Writ ==== Sometime before the [[History of Anglo-Saxon England|tenth century]], officials in England began utilizing writs to convey orders.<ref>Harper-Bill, Christopher. [https://books.google.com/books?id=FaI5tE6z07gC ''Anglo-Norman Studies, XXVII: Proceedings of the Battle Conference, 1994.''] Boydell Press (1995). 114-116.</ref> A "[[writ]]" was simply a short written command issued by a person in authority. It was customary for the sender to [[Great Seal of the Realm|seal]] this written command as proof of its authenticity. In the days when writing was a rare art, a writ was revered because the person receiving the command was unlikely to deny or question its legitimacy.<ref>Jenks, Edward. [http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2956&context=ylj ''The Prerogative Writs in English Law''.] The Yale Law Journal 32.6 (1923): 523-534.</ref> The [[Norman Conquest of England]] in 1066 led to the establishment of a strong, centralized monarchy. The first [[Normans|Norman]] [[King of England]], [[William the Conqueror]], modified writs to become mainly framed in Latin, increased the number of writs to cover additional royal commands, and established the ''[[Curia Regis]] '' in England.<ref>D. Douglas, ''William the Conqueror'' (London 1966) p. 293.</ref> The ''Curia Regis'', a Latin term meaning "royal council", consisted of the King of England and his loyal advisors. The ''Curia Regis'' accompanied the King as he travelled. This council administered all of the King's governmental activities, including judicial matters.<ref>Holdsworth, William Searle. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=gTJLAAAAYAAJ ''A History of English Law.]'' Vol. 1. Methuen, 1922. p 32-41.</ref>
One of the most important members of the ''Curia Regis'' was the [[Lord Chancellor]]. The Lord Chancellor led the chancery. [[Chancery (medieval office)|Chancery]] is a general term for a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] writing office that was responsible for the production of official documents.<ref>Corèdon, Christopher, and Ann Williams. [https://books.google.com/books/about/A_Dictionary_of_Medieval_Terms_and_Phras.html?id=RxJlQgAACAAJ ''A Dictionary of Medieval Terms and Phrases'']. Cambridge, England: D.S. Brewer, 2004. p. 66.</ref> The Lord Chancellor wrote writs on behalf of the King, maintained all official documents, and acted as the keeper of the [[Great Seal of the Realm|royal seal]]. This position, in effect, placed the Lord Chancellor as the head of the English legal system. The King, however, was the ultimate leader of the kingdom; therefore, the Lord Chancellor issued writs under the guidance of what he believed to be the best interests of the King. Between the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, the Lord Chancellor had a large control over issuance of all original writs. An original writ began a legal proceeding, while a judicial writ was issued during a legal proceeding.<ref>Holdsworth, William Searle. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=gTJLAAAAYAAJ ''A History of English Law]''. Vol. 1. Methuen, 1922. p 396.</ref>
==== Writ of error ==== One such "original" writ was the writ of error. In medieval England, the word "[[appeal]]" was not the term used to describe a request to review the legality of a lower court's decision. Instead, a "petition of error" requested higher courts to review the legality of an order or sentence. Petitioners brought a petition of error before the Lord Chancellor. Due to his position and close relationship with the law, the Lord Chancellor could naturally determine if the petition provided sufficient evidence of an error and, if so, the type of writ most appropriate to correct the error. If a lower court committed an error of law, the Lord Chancellor would issue a writ of error. A writ of error required the lower court to deliver the "records"<ref>The record only contained information on the arraignment, the plea, the issue, and the verdict. The record did not include the most material parts of a trial, including the evidence and the judge's direction to the jury. See Holdsworth, William Searle. [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=gTJLAAAAYAAJ ''A History of English Law]''. Vol. 1. Methuen, 1922. pp. 215-218.</ref> of the case to a [[superior court]] where the court reviewed the case for legal errors. Because a writ of error was only available for a higher court to determine if a lower court committed an [[Question of law|error of law]], courts needed another type of writ to correct its own decision upon an [[Question of law|error of fact]]. To rectify this issue, the Lord Chancellor created a new writ - the writ of error coram nobis. Thus, the original writ of coram nobis provided the means to correct errors that the writ of error could not correct. Unlike the writ of error, the writ of coram nobis: #corrected only factual errors that were not raised in the original case proceedings,<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7239470899724667152&q=coram+nobis&hl=en&as ''Bronson v. Schulten''], 104 U.S. 410, 416 (1882)</ref> #allowed the same court that presided over the original case to correct its own error, and #required the original case records to remain with the court that presided over the original case.<ref>Archbold, John Frederick.[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=yJVKAQAAIAAJ&oi=fnd&pg=234#v=onepage&q=coram%20nobis&f=false ''The Practice of the Court of King's Bench in Personal Actions, and Ejectment'']. No. 57603-57612. EB Gould, 1827 p. 234.</ref>
==== Writ of error coram nobis ==== “Coram nobis” is Latin for “before us”. Initially, when the Lord Chancellor issued orders on behalf of the King and the royal court, the word “us” simply referred to the King, the Lord Chancellor, and other judges of this court. The royal court originated within the ''Curia Regis'', which began during the [[England in the High Middle Ages|twelfth and thirteenth centuries]], under the realm of [[Henry II of England|Henry the Second]] (Henry II). Henry II made writs available for purchase by private individuals seeking justice, thus initiating a vast expansion of writs within the [[common law]].<ref>G. O. Sayles, ''The Medieval Foundations of England'' (London 1966) p. 305 and p. 332-333.</ref> The increased demand of judicial maters before the ''Curia Regis'' in the twelfth century led to the establishment of two central courts: the [[Court of King's Bench (England)|Court of King's Bench]] and the [[Court of Common Pleas (England)|Court of Common Pleas]]. These courts became the superior courts to all other courts in England, including local and tribunal courts such as the [[Hundred (county division)|Hundred Courts]] and [[Court of Piepowders]].
*'''The Court of King's Bench''' heard all complaints and pleas addressed to the King. This court was also known as the Court of Queen's Bench during the reign of a female monarch. Members of this court included the King and his closest advisors. This court always travelled with the King as he travelled throughout England and into other countries.<ref>Wiener, Frederick Bernays. [http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/abaj59&div=161&id=&page= ''Tracing the Origins of the Court of King's Bench''] ABAJ 59 (1973): 753-754.</ref> When the Lord Chancellor issued the writ to the court of King's Bench, the original full name of the writ was '''''quae coram nobis resident''''' or "Let the record remain before us". The words "let the record remain" indicate the court record of the original case remained with the court of King's Bench, unlike a writ of error, where the record moved to a different court. The words "coram nobis" ("before us") referred to the role of the King who served on the King's Bench. The King's place on the court of King's Bench became increasingly irregular; and by 1421, the King's Bench became a fixed court rather than one that followed the King. Although the King's presence was theoretical, the Lord Chancellor and his office continued to issue writs as if the King continued to as part of this court.<ref>Baker, J. H. ''An Introduction to English Legal History''. (2002). Butterworths LexisNexis. p. 39.</ref> *'''The Court of Common Pleas''' was authorized by [[Magna Carta]] to sit in a central, fixed location.<ref name=EB1911>{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Common Pleas, Court of|volume=6|page=779}}</ref> This court heard complaints and pleas that did not require the King's presence.<ref>Turner, R. (1977). [https://jstor.org/stable/844792 ''The Origins of Common Pleas and King's Bench'']. The American Journal of Legal History, 21(3), 245.</ref> When the Lord Chancellor issued the writ to the court of Common Pleas, the original full name was '''''quae coram vobis resident''''', or "Let the record remain before you". These words indicate that the records of the original case remained with the judges of the Court of Common Pleas so that it may review a case it previously decided to determine if an error of fact occurred.<ref>Prickett, Morgan. [https://digitalcommons.law.scu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1744&context=lawreview ''The Writ of Error Coram Nobis in California'']. (1990). Santa Clara L. Rev. 30: 1-48.</ref>
Over time, the authority to issue writs shifted from the Lord Chancellor to the courts. Although the King was no longer part of the court issuing the writ, the name "coram nobis" continued because courts associated the name with its function rather than its original Latin meaning. Thus, in English law, the definition of "coram nobis" evolved and is now redefined as a remedy for a court to correct its own error.<ref>Piar, Daniel F. [http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/nkenlr30&div=28&id=&page= ''Using Corum Nobis to Attack Wrongful Convictions: A New Look at an Ancient Writ'']. N. Ky. L. Rev. 30 (2003): p. 505.</ref>
====Abolition in English courts==== The first case involving the writ of coram nobis is unknown due to incomplete historical records prior to the sixteenth century; however, the first recorded case involving the writ of coram nobis occurred in 1561 in the case of ''Sir Gilbert Debenham and Another v. Bateman''.<ref>2 Dyer 195(b), See also Green, W. [https://books.google.com/books?id=I0QwAAAAIAAJ The English Reports. ''Debenham v. Bateman''] v4; v. 73. (1907) p. 430.</ref> Until 1705, the writ of error was originally a matter entirely up to the discretion of either the monarch or those with the authority to make decisions on behalf of the monarch; but in 1705, the court held that the writ was a matter of right instead of a matter of discretion. Despite making writs of error a matter of right, courts rarely used these writs because of their cumbersome and impractical procedure. A writ of error moved the record from the original court to a higher court; however, the record only contained information on the arraignment, the plea, the issue, and the verdict. The record did not include the most material parts of a trial, including the evidence and the judge's direction to the jury.<ref>Holdsworth, William Searle. ''[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=gTJLAAAAYAAJ A History of English Law]''. Vol. 1. Methuen, 1922. pp. 215-218.</ref> As a result, England abolished all writs of error, including the writs of coram nobis and coram vobis, and replaced them with appellate procedures encompassing all rights previously available through these writs. Thus, the abolition of the writ of coram nobis in England was due mostly to administration difficulties with the writ of error, and not because of administration difficulties with the writ of coram nobis itself. The law abolishing the writ in civil cases was the Common Law Procedure Act 1852.<ref>Common Law Procedure Act, 1852, 15 & 16 Vict., ch. 76, s. 148.</ref> The laws abolishing the writ in criminal cases was the Criminal Appeal Act of 1907.<ref>Criminal Appeal Act 1907, 7 Edw., ch. 23, s. 20.</ref>
===United States=== After arriving in North America in the [[17th century|seventeenth century]], [[British colonization of the Americas|English settlers]] established [[Thirteen Colonies|English colonies]]. Within these colonies, the settlers created colonial courts that adhered to the [[English Law|English legal system]] and issued writs in the same manner as English courts. After the United States obtained [[American Revolution|independence from England]], state governments, as well as the federal government, [[Reception statute|provided courts the authority to continue to rely]] upon writs as a source of law unless issuing the writ violated the state or federal constitution or if either the state or federal government subsequently enacted a statute restricting the writ.<ref>Chemerinsky, E. (1986).[https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1667&context=faculty_scholarship ''Thinking About Habeas Corpus'']. Case W. Res. L. Rev., 37, 748, 751.</ref> The purpose of allowing courts to issue writs was to fill a void whenever the state constitution, state statutes, the U.S. Constitution or federal statutes did not address an issue to be decided before the court. Writs were especially important when the federal government, as well as each state, first established its judicial system. During those times, there were very few (if any) statutes or case laws for courts to rely upon as guidance. In those circumstances, the English writs provided fledgling federal and state courts an important source of law. Over time, writs became significantly less important as Congress and state legislatures enacted more statutes and further defined rules for its judiciary. Writs also evolved independently in the federal judicial system and each state's judicial system so that a writ within one judicial systems may have a vastly different purpose and procedures from the same writ in other judicial systems.<ref>Wilkes, Donald E., ''Federal and State Postconviction Remedies and Relief''. Harrison Company, 2001. p. 55-58.</ref> Different characteristics of a writ from one judicial system to another is the result of the [[Federalism|federal]] system of government prescribed within the United States Constitution. [[Federalism in the United States]] is a mixed system of government that combines a [[Federal government of the United States|national federal government]] and [[State governments of the United States|state governments]]. While federal courts are superior to state courts in federal matters, the Constitution limits the reach of federal courts; thereby, providing state courts general sovereignty and law-making authority over a wider range of topics. This sovereignty allows each judicial system to decide whether to adopt writs and the function and purpose of each writ it adopts. Thus, the use and application of writs, including the writ of coram nobis, can vary within each of these judicial systems.
Legislation authorizes a judicial system to issue the writ of coram under one of two conditions: #Where legislation permits courts to issue writs, but the legislation does not specifically mention the writ of coram nobis. Courts throughout the United States generally have the authority to issue writs whenever the constitution or statutes encompassing a court's jurisdiction do not address an issue before the court and issuance of the writ is necessary to achieve justice. This authority was especially important for earlier courts when there were few statutes or case law to rely upon. Over time, legislatures enacted statutes encompassing almost all issues that could arise before a court. As a result, courts today rarely need to rely on writs as a source of law to address an issue not covered by statute. One example of a rare issue where courts have the occasion to issue the writ of coram nobis is the issue of former federal prisoners who have new information and this new information would have resulted in a different verdict if the information were available at the time of trial. Whenever this specific issue comes before a federal court, there is no federal statute that specifically guides or regulates how the court must proceed; however, federal courts have determined that the writ of coram nobis is the proper vehicle to achieve justice under this specific issue. #Where legislation specifically permits courts to issue, by name, the writ of coram nobis. The use of writs in the United States is more common when legislation has authorized a writ by name and regulated its use by courts. For earlier courts, the practice of issuing writs was an integral part of the judicial system's proceedings. Therefore, when legislatures enacted laws to regulate issues associated with writs, some legislatures adopted the exact name of the writ within its rules while other legislatures chose to abolish the names of the writ but provided an alternative remedy under a different name. Tennessee is an example of a state where its legislature enacted a statute expressly authorizing courts to issue, by name, the “Writ of Error Coram Nobis” and regulated how this writ should be issued.<ref>[https://law.justia.com/codes/tennessee/2017/title-27/chapter-7/ Tenn.Code Ann. § 27-7 (2017)]</ref> In contrast, other states replaced the writ of coram nobis with other post-conviction remedies. For example, the Pennsylvania legislature enacted a law on January 25, 1966 that expressly abolished the name “writ of coram nobis” and encated the state's Post Conviction Relief Act, which is now the sole means for obtaining post-conviction relief.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=4875028688006369069&q=coram+nobis&hl=en&as ''Commonwealth v. Descardes'', 136 A.3d 493, 497-502 (Pa. 2016)]</ref>
==Coram nobis in United States federal courts== [[File: Coram nobis Timeline in US federal courts.png |thumb|500px|right|Historical dates for the writ of coram nobis in federal courts and post-conviction remedies for former federal prisoners.]] In 1789, Congress passed the Judiciary Act to establish the judicial courts in the United States. This Act also allows courts to issue writs, including the writ of coram nobis. Originally, federal courts applied the writ of coram nobis only to correct technical errors, such as those made by a clerk of the court in the records of the proceedings. The 1914 Supreme Court case ''United States v. Mayer'', expanded the scope of the writ of coram nobis to include [[fundamental error]]s, but the Court declined in this case to decide whether federal courts are permitted to issue the writ of coram nobis.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3748662799506034506 ''United States v. Mayer'', 235 U.S. 35, 69 (1914)]</ref> In 1954, the Supreme Court determined in ''United States v. Morgan'' that federal courts are permitted to issue the writ of coram nobis to correct fundamental errors, such as those where discovery of new information is sufficient to prove a convicted felon is [[Actual innocence|actually innocent]].<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9872030110034150799 ''United States v. Denedo'', 129 S. Ct. 2213, 2220 (2009)]</ref> Since the ''Morgan'' case, federal courts traditionally issue a writ of coram nobis whenever a former federal prisoner petitions the original sentencing court to set aside the conviction based upon new information that was not available when the petitioner was in-custody and where this new information demonstrates that the conviction was a result of a fundamental error.
===History of the writ of coram nobis in federal courts from 1789 to 1954=== ====The Judiciary Act of 1789==== The history of the writ of coram nobis in United States federal courts began in 1789 when Congress enacted the [[Judiciary Act of 1789|Judiciary Act]]. Under Section 14 of the Judiciary Act, federal courts have the authority to issue a [[writ]] whenever the court deems it necessary to achieve justice and whenever no congressional law covers the issues before the court.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=001/llsl001.db&recNum=204 1st Congress, 1st Session, 1 Stat. 81-82.]</ref> This section was known as the “All-Writs Provision” of the Judiciary Act until 1948 when it became more commonly known as the “All-Writs Act” after Congress modified the Judicial Code and consolidated this provision into {{UnitedStatesCode|28|1651}}.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9932283031886059336 ''Pa. Bureau of Correction v. U.S. Marshals Service'', 474 U.S. 34, 40-41 (1985)] Since 1789, there have been only a few subtle amendments to the act, but none of the amendments have significantly changed the substance of the act from its original form. In 1911, Congress adopted the [[Judicial Code of 1911|Judicial Code]] which organized all laws, or statutes, into the ''Code of Laws of the United States of America'' (commonly known as [[United States Code]] and abbreviated U.S.C.). In 1948, Congress modified the code for the All Writs Act under 28 U.S.C. § 1651(a) where it remains today.</ref> Under the All Writs Act, federal district courts have the “power to issue writs of [[scire facias]], [[Habeas corpus in the United States|habeas corpus]], and all other writs not specifically provided for by [[statute]].” Congress had not specifically provided by statute the authority for federal courts to issue a writ of coram nobis; therefore, the All Writs Act provides federal courts this authority.<ref>The All-Writs Act only provides federal district courts the ''authority'' to issue writs; but, it does not provide federal district courts the ''jurisdiction'' to hear and issue writs. District courts have the jurisdiction to entertain writs, including a petition for the writ of coram nobis, under {{UnitedStatesCode|18|3231}} which confers on the district court original jurisdiction over "all offenses against the laws of the United States." See [https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=6762057459713035389&hl=en&as ''United States v. Wilkozek'', 822 F. 3d 364, 368 (7th Cir. 2016)].</ref>
The first case in a federal court to address the writ of coram nobis was ''Strode v. The Stafford Justices'' in 1810.<ref>23 F. Cas. 236 (C.C.D. Va. 1810) (No. 13,537). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ljhFAAAAYAAJ ''Reports of Cases Decided in the Circuit Court of the United States for the Fourth Circuit: (1792-1883)'']. Volume 1. (1837) p. 162-165.</ref> In this case, the Supreme Court Chief Justice [[John Marshall]] wrote the opinion in this Circuit Court case and held that the writ of coram nobis is distinguishable from the writ of error and therefore not subject to the writ of error's statute of limitations. The first Supreme Court case mentioning the writ of coram nobis (using the term coram vobis) is the 1833 case, ''Pickett's Heirs v. Legerwood''.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=134783638943220731&q=coram+nobis&hl=en&as ''Pickett's Heirs v. Legerwood'', 32 U.S. 144, 147-148 (1833)]</ref> In this case, the Court determined that the writ was available to correct its own errors, but the same remedy was also available using the preferred method of submitting a motion to the court. Eighty years later, in 1914, the Supreme Court reached a similar conclusion in ''United States v. Mayer''.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3748662799506034506&q=coram+nobis&hl=en&as ''United States v. Mayer'', 235 U.S. 55, 67 (1914)]</ref> Thus, while federal courts confirmed the writ of coram nobis was available to federal courts, this remedy was rarely necessary or appropriate in federal courts throughout the nineteenth century for the following two reasons: #Courts generally considered the writ of coram nobis to be restricted to correct only technical errors, such as discovery of a defendant being under age, evidence that a defendant died before the verdict, or errors made by the court clerk in the recording of the proceedings.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9872030110034150799 ''United States v. Denedo'', at 2220.]</ref> #Petitioners could raise a “motion to amend” to correct most of errors also corrected by the writ of coram nobis. Although courts recognized that the writ of coram nobis could also reverse the judgement on such defects, the preferred practice was to present the court with a motion to amend.<ref>''United States v. Plumer'', 3 Cliff. 28 (Circuit Court of Massachusetts, 1859) published by {{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yl1GAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA538&lpg=PA538#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Federal Decisions: Cases Argued and Determined in the Supreme Court and District Courts of the United States, Volume 1|date=1884|page=541|last=Myer|first=William G.|publisher=The Gilbert Book Company |website=books.google.com |access-date= July 8, 2018}}</ref>
====1946 amendments to the Rules of Civil Procedure ==== In 1946, Congress amended the [[Federal Rules of Civil Procedure]] and specifically abolished the writ of coram nobis in federal [[Civil procedure in the United States|civil cases]]. Prior to enactment of these amendments, Congress reviewed all relief previously provided for civil cases through the writ of coram nobis and adopted those avenues of relief into the rules; therefore, eliminating the need for the writ in federal civil cases.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.uscourts.gov/rules-policies/archives/committee-reports/advisory-committee-rules-civil-procedure-june-1946|title= Advisory Committee on Rules of Civil Procedure - June 1946|date= June 1, 1946|website= uscourts.gov|access-date= July 6, 2018}}</ref> In the amendment, Congress expressly abolished the writ of coram nobis in Rule 60(b).
